Place: The Giddy Goat Coffee Roasters | South End
Description: Spacious and stylish coffee shop in South End with a bright, modern interior and a laid-back community feel. Known for its excellent coffee, fresh empanadas, and friendly staff.
Comments:
This is their newest location in South End, with the original spot still going strong in Plaza Midwood. This one completely lives up to the hype. Honestly, I’d go so far as to say it’s the best place to hang out in South End if you’re a remote worker, a student, or just someone looking for a spot to plop down with your laptop.

Access to outlets is tremendous. Truly 10/10. You can tell there was an intentional effort to make it easy to stay charged, and I love whoever made that decision. There’s plenty of seating both inside and out, and the outdoor setup is quality. There’s a ground-level patio and an upstairs patio, and both have outlets. Outdoors! They even have the little plastic covers to keep them protected from the elements, so you can sit in the sun, plug in, and just relax.

They’ve got pastries (no cinnamon rolls, unfortunately) but some solid options, plus empanadas and other grab-and-go bites. It’s already a popular remote work spot. Every time I’ve been, there’s a steady group of people hanging out, working, and enjoying the space. The design is excellent, with plenty of room to spread out, good energy, and great coffee. I’m more of a tea person, but they’ve got that too, with some solid choices.

The only real concern is parking. There’s free street parking, but this is South End, so it’s limited, and apartments nearby make it competitive. There are some paid lots further down the street if needed.

The upstairs patio is also a great place to read on a warm day, with solid views and a calm atmosphere. Overall, this is an incredible addition to the South End coffee shop scene. I’d choose this place over nearby Not Just Coffee, Stable Hand, Salted Melon, and even Suffolk Punch, which has long been one of my favorites in the area. It’s that good.

Address: 15205 John J Delaney Dr Ste B, Charlotte, NC 28277
Description:
The country of Yemen is unapparelled to any other place on this Earth. From its breathtaking scenery to its history that dates back to the beginning of man. Yemen is the homeland of our family. As first-generation immigrants, we wanted to honor our heritage.

Yemen is where coffee was invented and later flourished in global trade. Roasting and serving coffee is something that is inclusive of all people and cultures and brings people together. Our coffee is grown from altitudes over 3,000 ft in a mountainous village called Haraz, where our namesake originates.
Comments:
As beautiful as all their other locations. This one is now my favorite compared to their Elizabeth and LoSo spots since parking is super easy (it's in a shopping complex with a huge lot), and access to outlets is truly marvelous. 10/10. There was an intentional effort here to make sure people coming to work on laptops or study could stay charged up and I appreciate it.

Aside from that, if you've been to any of their other locations and enjoyed it, this is worth a visit. They're open late as well, so its a great spot to meet friends, study, work, do whatever you need to, late into the evening. And Ballantyne is one of the nicest suburbs of Charlotte. Check out Ballantyne's Backyard and the The Bowl at Ballantyne (right across the street) while you're here. There's a whole project called Ballantyne Reimagined that focuses on adding more and more cool stuff to the area. They've already done a great job!

Description: Bustling taproom & beer garden offering in-house sandwiches & international food-truck fare.
Comments:
Gigantic space. I don’t think there’s any other place listed on this website that’s bigger than this one. Two floors. The ground level has a ton of seating, plus even more if you count the connected building’s lobby area, which also has places to sit. There’s an outdoor patio downstairs with plenty of seating, and upstairs there’s another patio that wraps around the building and is just as big. There’s room for you, your whole family, and probably your extended family too.

Access to outlets is marvelous. Splendid. 10/10. If you’re coming to work remotely, you’ll be fine staying charged up. This is one of my favorite places to work from in South End on a weekday morning because it’s so big that you can find a quiet corner and practically have it to yourself until the afternoon crowd starts to roll in. Oh, and if you’re into people watching, this is also a great place for it. There are plenty of seats alongside the Rail Trail where you can sit, sip, and be nosy.

Now, they have all that seating for a reason. Once the South End crowd gets off work, this place fills up fast. It can be overwhelming. The first time I came was a Wednesday evening, which was a mistake for me since I prefer a more laid-back vibe and don’t love crowds or the energy that comes with them. But really, it just depends on when you visit. If you’re feeling social and want that outgoing, energetic atmosphere, come in the evening. If you want something quieter to read, study, work remotely, have a meeting, or catch up with a friend, come on a weekday morning and you’ll get exactly that.

I’m typing this on a Thursday morning here at Sycamore, and it’s me and maybe ten other people in a space that easily fits over a hundred. They’ve got “Yellow” by Coldplay playing in the background, which perfectly fits the calm morning vibe. There’s a coffee bar downstairs with tea and specialty drinks like matcha and chai, and you can order food throughout the day using the QR codes placed around the space.

Most importantly, what impressed me the most is that there are outlets all around the outdoor seating on the upstairs patio. If it’s warm out and you want to sit outside with your laptop and stay charged up, this is a top-tier spot.

The biggest challenge here is parking. The lots right next to the building are paid, but there’s a workaround. If you’re willing to walk a bit, you can park for free at Atherton Mill, which has both outdoor spots and a free garage. It’s less than a five-minute walk. There’s also a lot near Elon University down the street, but that one’s a bit riskier since it’s meant for specific businesses, so there’s a small chance of getting towed. Still, Atherton Mill is so big and has so many businesses that I doubt anyone would care if the place you’re visiting happens to be right around the corner instead of inside the Mill itself.

Place: To The Table Board Game Cafe
Description: Cozy board game cafe in Matthews offering a rental library of modern board games, trading card games, and role-playing games alongside drinks and light snacks. Guests pay a modest table or game fee, pick a title from the shelves, and settle in at cafe style seating or themed rooms for a few hours of play with friends or organized events like Commander and D&D nights. Located in a neighborhood shopping center with on site parking and free Wi-Fi, it caters to both serious gamers and casual groups looking for a laid back spot to play, meet new people, and try new games.

Address: 6908 Matthews-mint Hill Rd #350, Mint Hill, NC 28227
Description: Family friendly tabletop shop in Mint Hill with walls of board games, card games, and RPG supplies plus plenty of in store tables for open play. A large game library lets you try new titles in the space or rent them to take home, and there are private rooms and regular events for RPGs, trading card games, and miniatures. Located in a suburban shopping center with easy lot parking, it functions as a community hub where locals drop in to browse, learn new games, and spend hours playing with friends.

Downtown Concord game and hobby shop located in a historic former bank building, offering a wide selection of board games, trading card games, RPGs, puzzles, and miniatures. The main floor doubles as a retail space and play area, with multiple tables set up for casual gaming, tournaments, puzzle competitions, and regular events for games like Magic, Pokémon, and Warhammer.

The staff are known for being welcoming and knowledgeable, helping new and experienced players find the right games or cards. Snacks, soft drinks, and treats are available, free Wi-Fi makes it easy to look up rules or deck lists, and customers typically spend several hours here during leagues and events. Parking is via nearby public decks and downtown street parking.

Type: Comic Book Store,Game Store,Ice Cream Shop
Description:
Neighborhood comic and game shop in Northwest Charlotte that combines new comics, graphic novels, and trading card products with a family friendly play space. The current location has an expanded seating and group play area, plus a connected ice cream counter offering shakes, floats, and a big selection of cold drinks.

Regular events for Magic the Gathering, Pokémon, Dungeons & Dragons, and other games draw a consistent community of players of all ages. Private lot parking is available on site, and the vibe is more hang out and play games than sit quietly and work on a laptop.

Address: 1640 Sardis Rd N Ste 110, Charlotte, NC 28270
Description:
Board game cafe and wine bar in southeast Charlotte with a library of modern and classic tabletop games, a full coffee and tea program that includes a reservation only coffee omakase at the bar, and a menu of sandwiches, waffles, gelato, and small sweets.

Guests can reserve time or walk in to play from a curated list of family friendly and strategy games while enjoying espresso drinks, teas, beer, cider, and wine by the glass or bottle. The space is set up with a mix of lounge seating and game tables suited for couples, families, and small groups, and offers free Wi-Fi for light laptop use between turns.
Outpost of a local mini-chain for organic produce, wine, craft beer & gourmet meats & cheeses.
Comments:
Has some solid outdoor seating on the rail trail, great for people watching, or watching the light rail go by. They've gone viral a few times, at least within Charlotte, for their hot sandwiches. Small interior but there are tables here and there and free Wi-Fi (ask staff for the details, and a hint, it's a capital H and capital G in the password).

I'd say this space is best suited for using their patio to meet friends and chill. If you need more space, it’s a short walk from Night Swim and Sycamore Brewing. So, on this one strip you’ve got plenty of third places.

Description: Specialty coffee shop from a local Charlotte roaster serving carefully crafted espresso drinks, drip coffee, and rotating single origin offerings, along with a small selection of pastries. Known for consistent quality, attention to detail, and baristas who can help you choose something new, it is a reliable stop whether you are grabbing a quick coffee or exploring more adventurous seasonal drinks.
Comments: Super small, most of the seating is coffee bar style with high chairs. Sycamore Brewing, which is gigantic, is across from it though so you can get expand there if you’re struggling to find a place to sit.

Address: 1101 Central Ave Unit B, Charlotte, NC 28204
Description: Intimate vinyl listening bar tucked inside the lobby of a boutique hotel on Central Avenue, with a cozy lounge, projector visuals, and a high-quality sound system focused on curated DJ sets and deep cut playlists. Expect craft cocktails, wine, beer, and a few spirits free options, but no kitchen, so you'll need to bring or order in your own food.
Comments:
Found by a friend of mine, Alex Jones (not the controversial right-wing figure, this Alex is a black woman, just an unfortunate coincidence with the name, she's way cooler than the other Alex Jones). 

This is in a unique hotel called Hotel Refuge, worth checking out, they have an interesting story. The space itself for the bar is small with limited seating that suits dates or groups of four or fewer, and it can get busy on weekends, so reservations are recommended. I'd say it works best as an evening hangout spot for music lovers rather than a full-on work or study space.

Description: 21+ Amsterdam style cannabis lounge and coffee bar in South End with a cozy indoor lounge and a turf patio set up for social smoking. Expect regular and infused coffee drinks, zero proof mocktails, and a rotating pastry case, plus occasional infused treats. The space doubles as a hangout spot with board games, weekly trivia, DJ nights, and four big TVs, and it is set up for laptop work with tables and power during quieter hours.
Comments: If you're a pothead, you'll love this place.

Description: Compact bubble tea shop off SC-160 in a newer retail strip, serving made-to-order milk and fruit teas with assorted toppings, basic indoor seating, and a private parking lot shared with neighboring tenants.

Address: 9605 N Tryon St Ste Y, Charlotte, NC 28262
Description: Small bubble tea shop in a busy plaza, offering the standard Kung Fu Tea lineup of milk and fruit teas with customizable toppings, Wi-Fi, and access to the shared parking lot out front.
Spacious bubble tea shop on South Blvd with plenty of room to sit and hang out, serving a large menu of milk teas, fruit teas, slushes, and toppings, plus free Wi-Fi and on-site lot parking.

Address: 9715 Sam Furr Rd D, Huntersville, NC 28078
Description: Compact bubble tea shop in Northcross Shopping Center offering customizable milk and fruit teas, Korean fried chicken, Korean hot dogs, egg waffles, and desserts, with a decent number of tables for casual hangouts or study sessions.
Modern bubble tea and snack shop in Plaza Midwood serving milk teas, fruit teas, fried chicken, and Hong Kong–style egg waffles inside a sit-down cafe space with shared parking off Central Ave.
Coffee bar tucked inside Compare Foods, a Latin supermarket on South Blvd, serving espresso drinks, flavored lattes, and Latin-inspired treats from a small counter near the front of the store.
Comments:
This is the definition of a hidden gem. You have no way of knowing it's there unless you hear about it somehow. Nothing indicates its presence just driving by. It's a cool spot inside Compare Foods.

You can order a a drink, then grab a seat in the shared dining area used by the in-house restaurants, with plenty of room for a quick meeting or a short laptop session in what is a pretty lively grocery store setting.

Expect a steady hum of shoppers rather than café-quiet. Parking is free and easy, huge lot for the grocery store. And the menu has a lot of great stuff that leans into Latin flavors rather than traditional American coffee shop items.

Description: Coffeehouse/full bar offering live music & comedy nightly in a relaxed setting with outdoor seating.

The Photo Outfitters is a community focused camera shop and film lab offering new and used gear, film developing, darkroom and studio rentals, and photography classes for all levels. It doubles as a hangout spot for local photographers, with a living room style seating area where people can meet, talk shop, and plan their next shoot.
Comments:
If you're into photography, this is your third place. The owners quite literally used the words "third place" when discussing what they want the space to be on this podcast. The heart of the space is the lounge area, with a deep blue couch, coffee table, walls full of framed prints, and a big world map dotted with pins where photos were taken. 

You're welcome to sit, ask questions, and stay a while without buying a thing. They host meetups, classes, gallery nights, and gear events, so the space is constantly rotating between shop, classroom, and clubhouse for Charlotte’s photography crowd.

If you want something to drink, grab a coffee at Night Swim | Oakhurst right around the corner, then wander over here to hang out and talk all manner of photography nerd stuff to your hearts content.

Description: Counter-serve bakery/cafe chain serving sandwiches, salads & more, known for its bread & free WiFi.
Comments:
This is my favorite Panera in the greater Charlotte area. It's huge, not only the main seating area, but they have a conference room that's sometimes not booked, so you can go in there and sit as well. Between the inside and outside seating, it'd be impossible to come here and not find a place to sit. Other than that, it's a Panera Bread. You know what it is.

There's a seating booth here that's to your right as you walk in that's an excellent spot to plop down. It's back aganist a wall, and when you're seated there's a half wall with a window into the bakery area that blocks your view of the rest of the space. So, most visual distractions are gone. I'm typing this comment from there right now. If you're reading this comment and ever come here, try to snag that spot. But if I also happen to be coming in and see you there, we'll have to fight for it 🥊😂. Jokes aside, it's a prime spot to lock in, study, work remotely, get some reading done, have a private conversation, whatever it is you do.

Address: 7714 Matthews-mint Hill Rd, Mint Hill, NC 28227
Description: A black woman owned cultural gallery, tea lounge, and bookstore, all in one intimate space. It features rotating Black art, The Ebony Shelf’s curated selection of books by Black and minority authors, and the Ebony Bloom Tea Lounge for tea service, treats, and community events in historic Mint Hill.
Comments:
This spot is a whole ecosystem of Black culture tucked into a single Mint Hill storefront. Inside, you have The Ebony Shelf, a bookstore where the shelves are heavy on Black and minority authors, the kind of titles that never get the center table at the big chains. There are children’s books, suspense, memoirs, and all sorts of random gems.

Inside that same space you have Ebony Bloom Tea Lounge, a full tea and coffee room in that old school afternoon tea style that's faded but is making a comeback (see The Pauline Tea-Bar Apothecary and A Cause for Tea). They have bistro tables, floral touches, teacups, and various photos of Black cultural icons. The owner is very intentional about this being a welcoming place, especially for the Black community, encouraging you to dress up a bit if you want and make it a spot of your own. Given that I, the creator of this site, am black, I love it!

Then there's the art gallery side, which is basically an open invitation for local artists to take over, hang their work, and host whatever gathering fits the moment. It's one building boasting a bookstore, tea lounge, art gallery, and community room all weaved together and inspired by Black culture.

It's a third place true and through. You can browse a new-to-you Black author, sip tea, and then stick around for an art opening or a themed night. Check out their Google Maps profile and Instagram for exact hours of operation. It's worth a visit!

Description: Seattle-based coffeehouse chain known for its signature roasts, light bites and WiFi availability.
Comments:
There are book clubs that meet here and love the space. There's plenty of seating, and its top tier as far as Starbucks' go in terms of interior design. Access to outlets is excellent. There's a comfy booth style seating area, and some padded lounge chairs by the windows that are great for feeling nestled in. Then there's a bunch of individual seating tables, and a very cool mural created by @napoletanoart that makes it feel less corporate coffee shop and more local spot.

Parking isn't great, but it isn't terrible as far as South End goes. There's a free lot, but it's shared with other businesses, so at peak times it can get packed. But at least there's a free parking lot. That's a win just in and of itself. Not all Starbucks are created equal. This is one of the better ones.

Description: Laid-back shop specializing in yeast-raised donuts, some with specialty fillings, plus coffee.
Comments:
Small, bright neighborhood shop with donuts, coffee, tea, cinnamon rolls (that I might argue are closer to a coffee roll, but I'll let it slide) and cute vibes. There's a handful of tables plus a cozy couch, and a couple of outdoor spots if you want to sit in the sun and eat frosting. Do not come here if you're trying to eat healthier. You'll fail.

This is very much a morning third place, the kind of spot where you meet a friend, read a book, catch up on some news, watch a few YouTube videos, think about your life and whether you're making sufficient progress toward the goals you set at the beginning of the year, reflect on the fact that by being in this shop eating a donut you're probably failing at at least one of them, and then walk out sugared up and happy.

Description: Bakery specializing in donuts such as apple fritters and buttermilk varieties, plus Vietnamese coffee.
Comments:
Owned by the same people as OMG Donuts & Bakery in Concord. It's a small space, but it still manages to fit a decent amount of seating so you can sit and hang out for a while. The business clearly encourages that since they provide fast and free Wi-Fi. The donuts, coffee, and ice cream are all really good. So if you’re on a diet, don’t come here. Everything is sweet, and everything is good.

They also sell cinnamon rolls, which, as a connoisseur in that field, I’d argue are more accurately described as coffee rolls, but I’ll let it slide. Mostly because on my first visit, a food truck called Cookin & Cruzin was parked outside, selling marvelous breakfast sandwiches and cinnamon rolls from Beyond Amazing Donuts. 

Beyond Amazing has long been on my list of best cinnamon rolls in Charlotte, currently surpassed only by Honeybear Bake Shop and tied for second with Sunflour Bakery. They’re thick, sweet, perfectly glazed, and powerfully pleasing cinnamon rolls. If you haven’t had one, it’s worth the trip to their location, formerly on Park Road and now in Uptown.

I’m not sure if Cookin & Cruzin is always posted up outside this place, but if they are, that’s a good and godly thing. OMG Donuts is a great spot to hang out, especially on a Sunday afternoon. If the food truck is around, you can grab a donut, a coffee, then hangout a bit, grab a breakfast sandwich, and a thick cinnamon roll all in one go. Praise be.

Description: Seattle-based coffeehouse chain known for its signature roasts, light bites and WiFi availability.
Comments:
If you're like "oh man Starbucks is boring, why is it on this website, what about the non-chain coffee shops", calm down alright. There's a lot of those on this website. I found myself here out of desperation, the nearby Night Swim closes at 5 PM, and I had a meeting right at that time I needed to be at a laptop for. This was the one of the closest results when I typed in coffee on Google Maps, and it worked quite well.

I would never tell you to go out of your way to come here. It's a cookie cutter Starbucks. But they have good access to outlets, and a decent amount of seating. They have booth style seating with around 8 small tables with outlets near each one. Then 5 or so tables by the window, no outlet access. Then the big table in the middle with outlets underneath it, and some lounge chair style seating. So, marvelous outlet access all around.

On my first (and only) visit here, a family came in and sat in the lounge seating, catching up, chatting, and petting their comically small, but very cute, dog. This place certainly is a third place for them, so it is for me. It's Starbucks, you know what it is. But it works. If you're in this area and want something truly local and nonchain, check out Visart Cafe and Julia's Cafe and Books.

A final note, I don't enjoy Independence Blvd. Having what is essentially a 5-lane highway right next to retail shops with people entering and exiting at wildly different speeds is some sort of masochist masterclass in road design. I came here out of desperation. I will only return under similar circumstances. There is no God-fearing reason to voluntarily sign up to drive on Independence Blvd.

They have marvelous, terrific, glorious, splendid, sizeable, positively charming cinnamon rolls. I first came here for that reason alone, and only after walking in discovered it's also a third place. There are a few seating spots, and they serve food as well. 

It's small, really small, but worth visiting, for the cinnamon rolls, and the chance that it's not too busy and you can snag a spot to sit down. Maybe best for meeting friends or family for a chat, rather than working remote or studying. Lovely none the less. Down to earth, local, and they have cinnamon rolls 🙌🏾.

Description: Coffee, vinyl, vintage, and books
Comments:
This is inside of a larger space called The District Exchange. They have their own corner though, and while small, it’s cool. There’s a bookcase, a case of vinyl records, and a large table for groups plus some smaller spots off to the side. So not a ton of seating, but there’s some more in the larger building that’s shared between all the shops. Outlet access, both here and in the entire space, is challenging, so charge your laptop if you're coming to work or study.

This whole area is nice though. Downtown Concord is like a Hallmark movie town. Family owned and local store fronts, bookstores, coffee shops, restaurants, a library, and all of it very walkable. There are a ton of third places in the area to hang out at, just check the map. If you’ve never been, it’s worth a trip. And if you come here specifically, there’s a bakery down the street called The Sweet Life with great cinnamon rolls.

Description:
Inspired by shopping arcades from around the world, the District Exchange’s vision is to showcase 22 Union as it was originally intended, as a thriving mixed-use epicenter for historic downtown Concord. Connect, create, shop, and dine across two expansive levels, including a reimagined mezzanine opening to the public for the first time since 1977. 

The District Exchange begins renovations early 2025 to become downtown Concord’s only multi-level retail and dining destination, featuring an inspired mix of staffed merchants and experiences—all under one roof.
Comments:
Large space with a bunch of shops inside, including Crane Coffee, which is easily the most welcoming spot in the building. There’s Wi-Fi, but it’s specific to each business, so your best bet is to grab something from Crane Coffee and ask for their password. 

Upstairs, there are some rocking chairs where you can sit and benevolently peer down at everyone below as they scuttle about fueling the American economy. Which is to say, they're excellent people watching seats. Aside from that, there's a few large tables, a few small tables, and then the seating within Crane Coffee. Overall, compared to the size of the building, there isn't a ton of seating, but what they have is sufficient.

Now, I wouldn’t call this place cozy, and it’s definitely not the spot to read quietly, study, or work remotely. It’s better for meeting friends, walking around, and chatting for a while. The whole Downtown Concord area has plenty of great third places, so if you haven’t explored it yet, it’s worth a visit. Just check the map!

Description: Coffee shop located in the beautiful Refinery building with a full host of food/beverage offerings (including of course, our home roasted coffee). See you soon!
Comments:
If you’re familiar with their Uptown location, it’s closed. Indigo Tea & Coffee Co. has taken over their old location. This is their new spot inside a larger building called The Refinery. The coffee shop is just a window inside. The seating is from the building itself, and there's not much of it. There are some tall tables with tall chairs, coffee bar style, and then two coffee table, couch, and lounge chair combo areas. 

One of them is half outdoors, which is actually pretty cool. It's at the far end of the hallway behind a glass door. There's a glass wall, two solid brick walls, and then the fourth "wall" is a half open window with plants adorning the sill. Top tier place to sit on a warm day and read a book, there's even outlets in that section, and the Wi-Fi reaches out there.

They have orange flavored cinnamon rolls 🔥🙌🏾 and serve properly steeped loose-leaf tea (no bag in your cup, just the brewed tea). Now, parking is in a paid garage, but they'll validate your ticket, so bring it in with you.

Aside from that, I'd say unless you really like what they're serving, this isn't a place to drive across town to work remote, study, or hangout at. The parking and the small space make it more of a convenience spot, if you're in the area, check it out for sure.

Description:
The Book Lady of Monroe specializes in used books. Walking into the store is a bit like stepping into Narnia’s Wardrobe or Dr. Who’s Tardis, there is so much more than is apparent from the outside. You can enjoy settling in one of the several cozy sitting corners to visit or read a while. Carol Gordon, The Book Lady, has made sure to fill every nook and cranny of her 3,900 square feet with a fantastic selection. 

From our exceptional children’s section and every genre of fiction and nonfiction including Christian, history, biography, art, science, home, gardening, health, crafts, cookbooks and more, The Book Lady of Monroe has it all. So stop in and browse, take a peek around the corner.
Comments:
Huge selection and really well organized, which is rare for a used bookstore. It’s so easy to find what you’re looking for here, and the prices are super fair. You can even trade in books if you want. If you’re a bookworm (✋🏽), you could get lost here for hours browsing.

This is everything a community used bookstore should be. I love it. Don’t bring your laptop when you come here, be free. Leave it behind, grab a book, bring a book, read, talk to people, be offline for a while.

There are cute dogs roaming around, Victorian-style chairs tucked into corners, and some comfy couches where you can plop down and read. The whole place feels warm, relaxed, and inviting. The owners will happily chat with you about books, art, puzzles, and anything in between.

Place: So Much More To The Story: A Bookery
Description: We are a book store that specializes in new books and new releases. We have prepared a selection of books and related items that have been specially chosen and organized for you. Whether you are looking for yourself or a gift for a friend or family member, we have some special options for you. We are happy to recommend some things we love and hope that you love them too!
Comments:
Adorable aesthetically. Whoever designed it clearly put a lot of effort into making it cute. It could honestly be a set for a Hallmark movie where the main character is some hotshot lawyer or banker from New York who comes home, stops by the local bookstore to be alone with their thoughts, and ends up running into their high school sweetheart they haven’t seen since graduation. They kind of look down on them for never leaving the small hometown, but they’re so charming that they start talking, go on a first date, and things take off from there. Yeah, that’s the vibe. Hallmark movie.

The book selection definitely leans younger. I wouldn’t call it expansive, but it’s solid. There’s a couch and a few chairs, not a ton, but if you can snag one it’s a nice spot to read for a bit. There’s some outdoor seating too, so you’ve got more options when it’s warm out.

Description: Bright and lively coffee shop serving good coffee, tea, & brekky burritos all day! A colorful and playful aesthetic, warm staff, and vibrant atmosphere!
Comments:
Super small, but it’s in The Bowl at Ballantyne with plenty to do and tons of outdoor seating. If it’s warm, you won’t worry about finding a seat. The inside seating is very unique looking. I'm not good at describing things, but it just doesn't look like a typical coffee shop set up. Very colorful, curves here and there in the design. I like it. The seats aren't comfortable though, just wooden backs, but if you're looking to stay awake and focused, then they're marvelous.

If you can snag a cubicle, you can post up and get some work done, there's even some outlets. The corner ones are my favorite. Feels kind of snug. Definitely bring noise canceling headphones though since it’s small and you can hear everyone within always.

This Charlotte Observer article said to order the Cumulus, described as “an iced matcha with toasted coconut, blue spirulina, and a cloud of cream, agave, and sea salt. If you’re not a coconut fan, skip it, but otherwise, this drink is a little work of art.” 

That sounds spot on for the kind of vibe this place has. I haven't yet gotten into matcha, despite recent rather persuasive attempts to win me over. If you try it, let me know how it is.

Right across the street, also in The Bowl, you have The Salty Donut with more indoor space and cinnamon rolls. Oh, and this place has cinnamon rolls too, orange flavored. So, if you drive down here you can do a whole cinnamon roll run with Fly Kid Fly, The Salty across the street, Sunflour Bakery nearby, and Smallcakes Ballantyne. Bro that’s four places to get cinnamon rolls in a small little area. I love Ballantyne.

Description: Provided Coffee is a coffee shop serving handcrafted espresso beverages and bottled drinks to the Greater Carolinas. Founded by two best friends at 18 years old, Provided aims to create an atmosphere of community wherever travelled. As coffee can act as a bridge of connection between others, the customer can expect "special experiences in unusual places."
Comments:
It’s got this grounded, modern vibe with concrete block walls that break up different parts of the space. Olive green and burgundy tones make it feel earthy and warm, and plants here and there tie it all together. It’s not quite industrial chic, it’s industrial something else that I don’t have the vocabulary to describe, but it’s very cool and earthy and I like it.

The lighting is warm, the colors are darker, and the whole place feels like autumn. Even the music fits the mood, with calming indie, dream pop, and a little bit of folk mixed in. There's a projector showing movies, sometimes black and white oldies, and other times whatever people want to see. The effort they put into the aesthetic really shows, and it deserves to be recognized.

I’ve been told their apple butter matcha is really good, but so is the plain matcha. Just straight up matcha powder and hot water. Try it. You'll get the most health benefits that way! It’s already a go-to spot for remote workers, with good outlet access and a decent amount of seating. It feels intentional. Like every part of it was designed for people to stay awhile. 

They have a location in Concord that's equally as awesome. It's attached to a thrift store inside with great finds. I've often felt I'd go there a lot if it was closer, so this NoDa location is a great alternative!

It's a library, and it is small. To me, there are no cozy seating spots here. It's either in the middle of the floor where you're surrounded by people, or back in a corner facing a wall while people walk the book shelves behind you. Still, it's a modern library, it's nice, but I don't like the seating arrangements.

That said, this is down the street from Sunflour Baking Company, Rocky River Coffee Co., and Verb Coffee | The Burg Church, so you've got plenty of options in the area if you don't like it here. Also, there's a newish YMCA around the corner. If you have a YMCA membership, you can go to any of them in the Charlotte area. This one is nice.

Address: 3775 Concord Pkwy S Suite 116, Concord, NC 28027
Description: Your Neighborhood Coffee and Ice Cream shop. Serving Hot and Iced Coffee, 24 flavors of Hersey's Ice Cream. Milkshakes, fresh bakery.
Comments:
Very cute place, small and compact interior, but it smells marvelous on account of the ice cream they sell. It's well adorned to be inviting and friendly with cushioned chairs here and there, various antiques like hockey tables and gumball machines, and even a kid's coloring section where they put up drawings.

Even the music they choose to play inside is very bubblegum, ice cream truck, happy, light, and sparkly. Feels like ice cream and happiness. Free Wi-Fi, not the best outlet access but there's a spot or two. There's one outdoor seating table. Lots of ice cream options, coffee, hot tea, but most importantly...

They have cinnamon rolls, and they are unique. It's neither cream cheese frosting nor traditional icing that adorns the roll. Instead, it's this caramely drizzle, I can't even say for sure it's caramel, but that's what stands in the place of the more traditional options. And it's light, the flavor isn't overwhelming, but it's not nonexistent. It's there, just existing to accentuate the flavors of the cinnamon roll without stealing the show. The result is a cinnamon roll where you can truly taste and enjoy the cinnamon. 

The icing doesn't overpower it, say for example the way any bottom tier mall variety cinnamon roll does, where they drench it in so much icing that you can't taste anything but gooey bread and sugar. That's not artistry my friends, that's not craftsmanship. Here, they opt for a lighter touch of icing, letting the cinnamon roll as a concept, as a pastry, as a craft, be the main show without distraction. I salute them.

Description: Vibe Café & Bar brings a unique experience to the Dilworth Neighborhood of Charlotte, NC. Not only is it a place where you can drop by for your morning cup of coffee and breakfast, but also where you can enjoy an original, soul food inspired menu with our European Cocktails, unlike you have ever tasted before.
Comments:
Relaxing wine bar vibes in terms of the aesthetic. Soft lighting, wood tones, touches of greenery (fake plants count) here and there. Lots of Russian inspired desserts that I've never heard of but all sound good, if not interesting. They have something called a chocolate sausage. It's not what you think. I mean, I didn't order it, but I at least asked. It's a sweet treat pastry is all I'll say, no sausage involved.

Good amount of seating, most of it indoors but there's some comfy lounge chair couches outside as well. Decent access to outlets, I counted 5 spots you could sit and access one, not bad at all for a place this size. Free Wi-Fi, and it's plenty fast, so you can plop down here to work or study. There's a very popular Starbucks across the street known for being busy, whereas things are usually pretty calm here. In that sense, it's a hidden gem.

The sink in the men's bathroom is very interesting. I had to look this up, but it's called a "cantilevered glass vanity", which to normal people is a "floating glass sink". Never seen anything like it, but I mean, I don't come from wealth. Oh, and they also have nice teacups. The handle has this curvature thing to it that wraps into the cup interior, very nice.

Last note, the parking garage has a sign that says 2-hour parking only, but I talked to the staff and apparently that's not enforced at all. You can stay longer and relax. But I mean, if you do get towed, definitely contact me so I can update this comment (and sorry, that's rough buddy).

Address: 917 Central Ave unit b, Charlotte, NC 28204
Description: Local Eastern Cafe located inside Sip City! We offer quality house made syrups, food and good vibes. We have plenty of room with comfortable couches, FREE WIFI. So, come in for your Daily Ritual! See you soon, cheers!
Comments:
Same building as Sip City Market & Bottle Shop. So, it just depends on the time of day you go, whether it's Daily Ritual or Sip City running things.

The vibe is creative and cozy, like a mini art gallery, with paintings from local artists on the walls and various card games on the tables. Most of the seating is four-person tables, but there are comfy couches mixed in and a bit of outdoor seating.

Good outlet access, and good tea options, including pure Japanese matcha. It’s right across the street from Central Coffee, a Charlotte staple that’s fantastic but super small. If you’re in the area and need more space, this is a great alternative. Turn into the lot next to Two Scoops Creamery for parking, spots are limited though.

Description: Good vibes. Relaxed atmosphere. We specialize in matcha and espresso.

Save on your favorite products and enjoy award-winning service at Publix Super Market at Arboretum Park. Shop our wide selection of high-quality meats, local produce, sustainably sourced seafood, and more. Try our signature items such as our Deli subs and Bakery cakes. Looking for something special? Our friendly associates are happy to help. Visit our Charlotte, NC store and see why shopping here is a pleasure.
Comments:
There’s a fairly large upstairs seating area on the entrance side of the building that makes this a third place. Students in the area seem to have caught on and can be found up there studying. Aside from that, it’s a Publix. Great deli (the chicken tender sub is 🔥) and hot food section, all other typical grocery items are available as well. Solid low key spot to plop down and get some work done. 

The seating feels secluded from the rest of the store on account of being upstairs. There’s even restrooms up there, so once you buy your stuff, you don’t have to go back down until you’re ready to leave. Also, access to outlets is surprisingly solid, so this is a gem all around.

Description: Located in Waxhaw, North Carolina, Virtuoso serves artisan bread and pastries with a twist of our own signature flavor. We also serve espresso, drip coffee, iced chai, and naturally sugared soda.
Comments:
I came here for cinnamon rolls not expecting it to also be a third place. So, I was pleasantly surprised walking in to see people sitting all around with their friends and loved ones, chatting, eating pastries, drinking coffee, and enjoying life. It’s in a converted house that’s pretty small, but they manage to have enough seating that Waxhaw families seem to regularly come here to hangout. So much so that they have coloring books for kids.

It’s a bakery known for its bread. Sourdough, focaccia, brioche, croissants, and more. But idgaf about all that, I came for their cinnamon rolls. At first glance, you might mistake it for a coffee roll, which is a doughnut, not a cinnamon roll. But upon closer inspection, there’s no doubt that what they serve here is a proper cinnamon roll. 

They opt for icing instead of cream cheese frosting, which means its best enjoyed warm (you can have a room temp cinnamon roll with cream cheese frosting, and it’ll taste fine, but icing demands warmth to shine). Once you warm this, it’s solid. Not transcendent, but solid. I still have Honeybear Bake Shop as my top spot in the region, with Sunflour Bakery and Beyond Amazing Doughnuts right behind them. That said, there’s so many third places in Waxhaw with cinnamon rolls that the whole city is worth a day trip. Just check the map (shout out the greatest map of all time).

Anyways, they also serve coffee and tea and have Wi-Fi, so if you can snag a spot, it’s not a bad place to study, work, or read. Just bring noise canceling headphones because it’s small to the point of being able to hear everyone in the house at all times.

Address: 116 E South Main St, Waxhaw, NC 28173
Description: The Daily Grind Coffee Bar serves Charlotte-based Night Swim Coffee, including espresso drinks and coffee flights. The menu includes smoothies and baked goods such as doughnuts, muffins, macarons, cake pops, and other pastries.
Comments: Small but they use the space well, and there's a bunch of benches outside for more seating. Good spot to check out on a warm day. Right in the heart of downtown Waxhaw, so within walking distance to a bunch of shops and other third places. Check out the map, downtown Waxhaw feels like it could be a set for a Hallmark movie. Very walkable, lots of store fronts, friendly people, good food.

Cool spot in an even cooler location (The Bowl at Ballantyne). The interior is small in terms of seating, but not compact. It doesn't feel cramped, and there are some larger tables where groups can sit. On warm days, there's a good amount of outdoor seating, so you can be reasonably sure you'll find somewhere to sit coming here. Outlet access is challenging, so charge your laptop if you're coming to work or study. 

Kind of a pricey menu, but that’s just the world these days. Blame inflation. Parking is free if you can snag a street spot and have the confidence to parallel park. If not, there’s a shared lot for all the businesses at The Bowl that gives you a few free hours. After that, you’ve got to pay.

Now, onto a topic of the utmost importance. They’ve got what is officially called a Honey Butter Cinnabun on their menu. Close enough. I’m counting it as a cinnamon roll. And it’s good, really good. Still, it leans more toward a donut than a traditional cinnamon roll. You don’t get that heavy, weighty interior with distinct coils that you could unravel. There's not that clear picture of something having been rolled up to create its present form.

You couldn’t pull this apart from spiral to straight. It’s all baked together like a soft bread roll. But it’s still delicious. So, it sort of borders on “can we really call this a cinnamon roll?” And to be fair, they do call them cinnabuns, not cinnamon rolls. Maybe for good reason. I'm certainly overthinking this. I am to cinnamon rolls what a pedant is to literature. I have issues. Ignore my ranting, their cinnabun is good, you should try it.

Description: The Salty Donut, an artisan donut & coffee shop located in South End, Charlotte.
Specialty coffee, local pastries, craft beer and wine.
Comments: Very compact interior, but what space they have, they use exceptionally well. There's a surprising amount of seating packed into such a small space, and it's done with superb access to outlets. There's some outdoor seating to spill over into if it's packed inside, which happens quite often here. It's a popular spot in a very busy business park. Parking is in a garage shared by the businesses in the area. Drive around, you'll find it.

Description: Tous les Jours means "every day"in French. Tous les Jours is a "French-Asian-inspired" bakery primarily serving a selection of baked goods and beverages.
Comments:
I've been told the Wi-Fi password is printed at the bottom of your receipt if you choose to get one. Otherwise, there’s a small sticky note near the checkout counter with it. Ask the staff if you can’t find it, although as an introvert myself, there’s a mild amount of social anxiety I get when asking for the Wi-Fi password only for the barista to point to a big obvious sign I somehow missed. So, yeah.

The layout here is pretty neat. There’s stadium-style seating with pillows, some lounge chairs, and a few tables with chairs both upstairs and downstairs. The main challenge is the truly abysmal access to outlets. If you’re planning to work here, charge your laptop ahead of time. Other than that, I like the vibes. The pastries are solid. Honestly, better than Amelie’s in my opinion.

Also, when Tous les Jours first came to Charlotte, I was like “wow, what a cool spot.” Then a friend from New York was like “lol, y’all really think this is special?” and I was embarrassed (NYC transplants in Charlotte please just go home if nothing here pleases or impresses you, stop bullying the rest of us for being simple and happy). Turns out they’re a chain. Not that that should change your opinion of them, just don’t go thinking it’s Charlotte local.

There's a pretty cool mural on the far wall towards the back of Marshall Park. If you've never heard of that park, that's okay neither had I. I had to use AI reverse image search to find the name. it often seems like nobody in Charlotte is from Charlotte, we're all transplants in this wonderful city.

But let me not be presumptuous. If you had heard of Marshall Park, go ahead and pat yourself on the back, and maybe consider making your way over here for a visit. They've got bubble tea (cold options only), food, a few pastries (no cinnamon rolls tho), and a decent amount of seating.

I find it a relaxing space, maybe because it doesn't seem to be that busy, at least in the evenings when I usually go. They've got a comfy couch, a faux fireplace, and a few plants (can't tell if they're real or not) scattered about. So, the relaxed vibes are intentional.

Description: Pho, Boba Tea, Mochi Donut, Vietnamese Sandwiches , Korean Pastries and Cakes, Korean Corn Dog, Vietnamese Street Foods. “One stop shop” where you can spend a “date out” with friends and family gather together to create more memories.
Comments:
Lots of Asian food options here alongside bubble tea, mochi donuts, coffee and tea. They have plenty of seating and Wi-Fi, although very few outlets, so if you're coming with your laptop, have it charged and ready. There's a Publix and Walmart in the same complex so you can get some grocery shopping done afterwards.

Also, it smells very much like an Asian food store. Very authentic, like everything that comes out of the kitchen was made by someone whose been making it their whole life. Like it's someone's aunt or uncle or grandma or something in there just going to work. The food tastes as good as it smells. Sample the menu, it's all good.

Description: Black-owned local bakery and cafe doling out coffee, tea, cakes, cookies, and other treats in a cozy space with live jazz on Sundays.
Comments:
A hidden gem in the truest sense. Really good pound cakes, but what stands out are the owners, Marilyn and Sam. They've made something special with this place. The live jazz on Sundays, the way Marilyn remembers everyone's name, the fact that they're only open three days a week because this is clearly a passion project. People from Cornelius call them 'treasures within the community' and that's exactly right. 

Yes, it's small. Yes, the hours are limited. But that's precisely what makes it a gem. I wouldn't ever come here to work on my laptop. Leave it behind, talk to people, maybe grab a corner and read a book, listen to some jazz, chat with some boomers, and brush it off when they start asking why you're still single and how they have a really nice grandchild you should meet 😅.

Description:
Our journey began with a love for bubble tea and a desire to share it with others. We saw an opportunity to bring something new and exciting, and we jumped at the chance to start our own business.

Our mission is to provide a high-quality and delicious drink option. We take pride in using only authentic ingredients and the highest quality tea leaves in our drinks. We believe that bubble tea should be more than just a drink - it should be an experience. That's why we strive to create a welcoming and friendly atmosphere for our customers.
Comments: Extremely compact, and yet for the space they manage to fit 6-7 two person tables. You’ll be sitting on top of the person next to you, but there is indoor seating, plus a few outdoor spots, so you can hangout if you’d like. Free Wi-Fi indicates they encourage and expect people to stay awhile. Their menu is a marvelous hodgepodge of fairly priced overly sweet items, including bubble waffles, ice cream, all sorts of iced teas, and my favorite, hot teas that you can get without sugar.

Address: 8960 J M Keynes Dr Suite 600, Charlotte, NC 28262
Description: Sharetea is the most authentic Boba Tea brand from Taiwan! Sharetea's Boba Tea, or called Bubble Tea are made from high quality tea leaves and selected ingredients shipped directly from Taiwan. All Sharetea's products are 100% guaranteed to arrive fresh and tasty.

Sharetea Steele Creek is where bubble tea fans and coffee enthusiasts unite in a charming space at 4922 Trojan Dr. Launched on November 4, 2024, this Charlotte hotspot offers an extensive selection of delicious bubble tea and coffee beverages along with pastries and snacks. Whether you're seeking a refreshing treat or a cozy spot to sip and relax, Sharetea Steele Creek welcomes you into a world of taste and serenity.
Comments:
It smells marvelous in here. Not sure what it is, but it’s a sweet and light aroma. Maybe it was just the day I went, idk. Smelled really good though. The place is small, but they managed to fit two stuffed animal vending machine claw game things. 

It has a very muted, minimalist aesthetic. Clean and uniform. Grays, whites, gold accents. It’s right next to a Wing Stop and Olive Garden, so if you’re hungry, get a drink here, get your food nearby. 

There’s Wi-Fi and 2 spots you can sit and reach an outlet, so you could come here to work or study. I wouldn’t though, seems like it’d be hard to focus. The entire store is always in view no matter where you sit. Good spot for meeting friends though, and drinking bubble tea if you’re into that.

Beautiful aesthetic, floral sort of thing going on, modern finish, smells very good. Bubble tea and donuts, plenty of flavors. And despite having really good access to outlets, they don’t have free wi-fi, so this is a no go for studying or remote work. Still worth visiting though if you just want to hangout, read a book, drink some tea, chat with friends, etc. Or if you’re willing to burn through your hotspot 🤣.

Description: Cabarrus County Public Library's Concord branch offers dedicated spaces for different age groups including a teen section with anime collection and an upstairs children's area separated from adult sections. Open Monday through Saturday, the library provides traditional services including book lending, community programs, and summer reading initiatives.
Connecting citizens with information & resources that educate, enrich, and empower.
Comments:
I love libraries. I didn't love this one. For a building so large, there's hardly anywhere to sit. And the book selection is rather limited. Now, what's great about this place is its location. As in, its proximity to other places that are better to hang out at. Downtown Concord has a lot, just check the map!

And to keep it 💯, a lot of people from Concord say this library feels more like a homeless shelter to them. I mean, they don't really bother anyone, but they're present throughout, so worth calling out. The kids' section is upstairs though and very clearly set up so that if you're not walking in with kids, it's like why you are up here, which I think is good design.

Description: Airy cafe/used bookshop benefiting Habitat for Humanity offers free WiFi & seating in a loft.
Comments:
It’s really nice to see a place that isn’t just industrial chic, super modern all-white "doctor’s office", or another cliché coffee shop aesthetic. Instead, it feels both clean and inviting, but also lived in. The upstairs loft is honestly one of my favorite places in Charlotte to read a book. There isn’t a ton of seating, but if you snag a spot, you can nestle in for hours, put your cares aside, and just enjoy some literature. Every so often, you can glance up at the huge art piece on the wall for something to look at.

Downstairs is the bookstore itself. It’s not huge and the selection isn’t on a Barnes & Noble level, but it feels authentic. The books really come from the community. Kids donate their grandma’s collections, students finishing school pay it forward, people leave their favorite titles because they have extra copies, and so on. The collection here feels more heartfelt than at other bookstores in the city.

They have coffee, tea, snacks, grab and go food, a few pastries and cookies, and most importantly, good vibes. There is usually a great early 2000s easy listening playlist. Think The Script, Kodaline, John Mayer, The Fray, Kelly Clarkson, Plain White T’s, Snow Patrol, Five for Fighting. All good stuff.

As a bonus, the shop connects internally to a Habitat for Humanity store, so you can do a little shopping after reading. Check their website for more details about the Habitat for Humanity connection.

Description: Gong Cha Ballantyne serves premium Taiwanese bubble tea with fresh-brewed teas and pearls prepared throughout the day. Known for its signature milk foam, the creamy sweet-and-savory topping pairs perfectly with classic and fruit teas. Founded in 2006 in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, Gong Cha is a global brand with strict quality standards.

Coffee shop offering specialty coffee, fresh pastries, and light breakfast and lunch options made daily. The cozy space features indoor and outdoor seating, with a quiet atmosphere suitable for working on laptops or casual dining. Popular menu items include various lattes, matcha drinks, and waffles, with kitchen service available until 3PM most days.

Address: 280 Concord Pkwy S Unit 5, Concord, NC 28027
Description: Verb Coffee operates this location inside Multiply Church, serving specialty coffee and pastries with limited hours primarily during mornings and early afternoons. The coffee shop offers dine-in and takeout options with free parking available in the church lot. Known for consistent quality coffee and friendly baristas, this location provides a quiet workspace atmosphere.

Verb Coffee operates this location inside The Burg Church in Harrisburg, serving specialty coffee, house-made pastries, and light fare with local ingredients. The family-friendly spot features a fenced playground for children and offers indoor seating with a quiet atmosphere suitable for work. Known for friendly service and quality coffee drinks including lattes and matcha options.
Comments:
If you've ever seen The Good Place or Bruce Almighty, this feels like a coffee shop straight out of their versions of heaven. It's so bright, pure-looking, and impeccably clean that it goes beyond the typical modern coffee shop aesthetic. It's as if someone deliberately designed it to resemble a café in heaven, or at least how heaven is often portrayed in movies and TV. The atmosphere is calming, and the space is airy, it doesn't feel like everyone is on top of each other. 

Outlet access is fantastic. I'm pretty sure you can charge your device from almost every single seat inside. But here's what really won me over. The men's restroom has complimentary mouthwash, Q-tips, band-aids, lotion, a lint roller, and body spray. As a man, I've spent a lifetime accepting that men's restrooms are usually borderline post-apocalyptic, while women's restrooms typically have luxury touches to them. This place actually cares about the men’s restroom experience, and I respect that. We deserve it Kings 👑.

Description: A locally owned shop serving Asian cuisine & specialty bubble tea.
Comments:
It's small and the chairs are uncomfortable, but the food is good, and it's usually not that busy outside of the lunch rush. So, it's a good place to plop down and have a meal with some friends, or get some work done quickly. The food is actually the highlight to me here, it's just in a corner of Charlotte nobody really goes to unless they work in the area, so it's not well known.

Also, I'm not into bubble tea but they have plenty of it, and it looks good. I refrain from participating in the bubble tea craze because I don't want to end up liking it and add all that sugar to my regular diet.

Description: Stop by The Gathering at Calvary Church for delicious brewed coffee, specialty beverages, and small bites! Just inside Calvary's main entrance Atrium, you'll find the café—a warm and welcoming space filled with natural light. Perfect for meeting friends and enjoying conversation and community.
Comments:
This place is a great excuse to visit Calvary Church, even if you're not religious, simply because of how beautiful it is. The external architecture alone is worth the trip. From the outside, it’s stunning. And on the inside, it’s massive, pristine, and modern in ways that surprised me. Calvary is known for being more traditional, the suit and tie kind of church, but the space feels fresh.

The coffee shop is tucked in a corner near the entrance. On its own, with both indoor and outdoor seating, it’s pretty spacious. And if it gets full, there’s plenty of extra lounge-style seating in the lobby that feels fair game for coffee shop patrons. There’s also a Christian bookstore and reading area called the Word Room that’s just as large as the shop itself.

As for the coffee, I’m not a coffee drinker, so I won’t pretend to be an expert, but it didn't appear to be anything remarkable. The tea options are pretty standard too, just your usual bagged selections. But the real draw here is the atmosphere. The peace and quiet, the beauty of the church, the solid access to outlets, the little umbrella-covered tables outside, and the chance to walk around the campus without needing to attend a service.

I'm a Christian, but non-denominational, so I probably wouldn’t have ended up at Calvary otherwise. I’m glad I came to see the coffee shop and explore the area. It’s a cool space.

Place: Carolina Beer Temple & the Ames Street Marketplace
Address: 215 N Ames St Suite 1000, Matthews, NC 28105
Description: Beer & bottle shop with rotating taps of craft brews plus hundreds of options by the can & bottle.
Comments:
Brewery with a bunch of smaller businesses inside that altogether comprise of Ames Market. Be sure to check out Two Scoops Creamery, and the bakery Innescas Sweets of Europe right around the corner. 

They have live music and family friendly pop up events every so often. There’s also arcade style games and a cannabis dispensary inside if you’re into that. It’s a nice area, park once and you’ve got plenty to check out and explore.

Description: Innesca’s Sweets of Europe – A European-inspired bakery in Matthews, NC specializing in delicate pastries, artisanal cakes, and gourmet coffee. From French macarons and mousse cakes to classic Eastern European desserts, every treat is made fresh with high-quality ingredients. Visit us for a taste of Europe, right in the heart of Matthews downtown.
Comments:
You know how doctor’s offices usually have a very white, polished, pristine aesthetic? This place has that, but with an elegance that makes it significantly more pleasant to hangout in. Idk if that’s a great description. My point is, it’s a beautiful space. Small, but well designed.

They serve coffee and tea, but as a bakery, their pastries are what stand out the most. No cinnamon rolls, but they’ve got a sweet cheese roll that’s pretty good, and ice cream cone shaped cake pops that taste as good as they look. 

And as an area, it’s a cool place to hangout, as there's a brewery in the same complex with lots of seating and family friendly events every so often. Together, they’re a great addition to the Matthews third place scene.

Description: At Platform Coffee, we’re all about people, building community, making connections, and serving exceptional coffee along the way. We roast all our coffee right here in Charlotte, so every cup is as fresh as it gets. Whether you’re stopping in for your daily go-to or meeting up with a friend, our team is here to welcome you with genuine hospitality and make every visit feel special.
Comments:
Same company as Platform Coffee + Kitchen but this is a different location in Matthews. Not much in the way of food options (hence the name Platform Coffee, not Coffee + Kitchen) but they have pastries, including rather good cinnamon rolls 🙌🏾🔥. There’s plenty of seating despite being a medium sized space, with good access to outlets at seats along the walls. It’s attached to New City Church internally, so they’re closed on Sundays, but any other day you’re good to go. 

Visually, it’s an industrial chic aesthetic, with the typical unfinished floor, but they go for black tables and chairs with blue and green pops of color here and there, rather than the all white doctor’s office look many similar spots prefer. Nothing standout, but it’s a nice place.

If you read the comments on this website, you’ll notice I never talk about the quality of coffee at places. I don’t drink coffee, I’m an herbal tea guy, and I stay in my lane. They have some solid herbal tea options here, so I was happy. I’m sure the coffee is great though, check the Google Maps reviews for more there.

Description: Coffeehouse chain serving signature drinks, mochas & lattes, plus coffee & breakfast.
Comments:
The nicest Caribou Coffee I’ve ever been to. Pristine, lots of space, solid outlet access, even the couch next to the faux fireplace has an outlet. Wooden floors, tables, and most chairs, but it’s that bright colored wood that looks like it was born yesterday.

Caribou has great sandwiches and an XL size for drinks that’s larger than the Starbucks Venti, so I always prefer their locations when they’re nearby. This one is lovely. Top tier study or remote work spot for those in the area. I wouldn’t say it’s a must visit for a day trip from Charlotte since it’s a chain, but if you’re nearby, it’s worth hanging out at for sure.

Description: Established cafe offering sandwiches, salads & breakfast, plus unique sweet teas & espresso drinks.
Comments:
Good access to outlets, especially along the tall chair bar-style seating. Someone clearly put effort into making sure people could stay charged up. Coffee Republic is expanding steadily across the Charlotte area, and I welcome it. All of their locations are quality.

This spot sits inside a converted industrial building with wooden floors, old brick walls, and stained wood finishes. It even smells like it, in the best way. They’ve jazzed it up with eclectic art, paintings, and little trinkets throughout. It’s a pretty neat space, and the surrounding downtown area is charming. Easy to walk around and explore local shops if you make the trip. Definitely worth a day trip from Charlotte.

Description: Military museum and coffee shop in downtown Mooresville, NC. Features military artifacts, memorabilia, and a "Book of Honor" with over 23,000 veteran signatures. Serves coffee and food. Open to veterans and the public. 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization providing veteran support services. Founded 1995.

Address: 500 S Main St Suite 112, Mooresville, NC 28115
Description: Specialty cafe and coffee roaster, offering hand crafted espresso drinks with fresh in-house roasted coffees from all over the world. Free wi-fi, plentiful seating, house made food and pastries.
Comments:
Calming space that leans into natural lighting, making it feel both comfortable and elegant. This is industrial chic at its best. The staff is warm and friendly. There are plenty of spots to sit, plug in, and settle in for work or study.

Solid tea options too. The Blueberry Rooibos is excellent. They also have coffee and food, and you can tell the owner put real effort into making this feel like a true third place. The layout invites you to linger. The booth-style seating is lined with soft oversized pillows, making it easy to sit a while without back pain. Greatly appreciated.

Address: 350 W Plaza Dr M, Mooresville, NC 28117
Description: RegalCha is a vibrant tea and coffee shop in Mooresville, NC, offering a wide variety of boba teas, fruit teas, smoothies, and specialty coffee drinks. Whether you’re craving a refreshing milk tea, a flavorful fruit blend, or a rich iced coffee, we’ve got something for everyone. We use premium ingredients and delicious toppings to deliver a fun and satisfying experience every time. Whether you're stopping by for your daily caffeine fix or a sweet treat with friends, RegalCha is your go-to spot for drinks with a royal twist.

Address: 120 N Cedar St Ste. 725, Charlotte, NC 28202
Description:
Welcome to Sugar & Sip Coffee and Workshop, where craft coffee meets community. We’re more than just a café, we’re a creative space serving specialty coffee, espresso drinks, and signature brews made with locally roasted beans. Whether you're here for a quiet morning pour-over or a bold iced latte, every cup is crafted with care.

Looking to deepen your coffee knowledge? Join one of our hands-on workshops, from barista basics to latte art and home brewing mastery, we offer immersive experiences for coffee lovers of all levels. Stop by for coffee, connection, and creativity, or explore our shop online to bring the café experience home.
Comments:
I like this place. Small but full of understated personality, and black-owned👏🏾 (the person behind this website is black). They have these pod seating things by the entrance that look cool. Very comfy. And it smells marvelous here, I believe because of a candle they have going somewhere. Limited menu compared to other coffee shops in Charlotte, but what they do serve, they serve well.

The interior design is very well done. Earthy, muted tones, a sort of modern minimalism, lots of natural light from floor to ceiling windows, a thoughtful orange-red accent wall bearing their logo, mid-century modern wooden chairs paired with cushioned benches. It's not your cookie cutter coffee shop design wise, someone put thought into making this place feel unique, reflect their personality, and they did a wonderful job.

Description:
Best in the City! We offer the most authentic and best-tasting bubble tea drinks, desserts and snacks. We only use the finest and imported loose-leaf teas to get the genuine flavor and brew them fresh daily. Our Tapioca Pearls (Boba) are carefully cooked and prepared several times daily to give you that rich, chewy goodness that everyone loves. 

Aside from the classic Bubble Teas, we have a wide selection of drinks and toppings that you can customize according to your preference. We also offer delectable snacks like our popular Japanese Popcorn Chicken, Fried Rice Cakes on Stick and Crispy Waffle Fries.

Address: 10032 University City Blvd B, Charlotte, NC 28213
Description: Coffee shop serving ice cream in addition to specialty coffee imported from a farm in Puerto Rico, featuring unique rum, whiskey, and tequila-infused blends.

August Lily Florist proudly serving the Monroe, North Carolina area since 2009, offering a wide variety of fresh floral arrangements and gifts to suit any style, occasion and budget. We're happy to assist you with local and worldwide deliveries, including daily deliveries to local funeral homes and hospitals.

We are a family-owned local business that is dedicated to the well being of our community. Our shop is a fresh new twist on an old local building. We have renovated a 100 year old residence on Benton Street to house fresh flowers, silk flowers, plants, artwork and an assortment of gifts.

Address: 9325 Jw Clay Blvd Suite 223, Charlotte, NC 28262
Description:
Discover the authentic taste of Yemeni coffee at Qamaria Coffee in University City, Charlotte, just minutes from the UNC Charlotte campus. We specialize in traditional Yemeni drinks like qishr and brewed coffee using freshly roasted beans and ancient brewing techniques.

Whether you’re a student, faculty member, or coffee lover, our cozy café offers a perfect space to study, relax, or catch up with friends. Located near JW Clay Blvd and the light rail station, we bring a unique Middle Eastern coffeehouse experience to the heart of Charlotte. Visit us today for rich flavors, welcoming vibes, and unforgettable coffee.
Comments:
A welcome addition to growing Charlotte Middle Eastern coffee shop scene which, as of 2025, includes Qahwah House, Haraz Elizabeth, Haraz LoSo, Vavela Cafe, Anatolia Cafe & Cuisine, and now Qamaria.

Haraz is rumored to be opening some new locations, and a spot called Bayt Al-Mocha is on its way to town sometime soon. They're all wonderful, although I still give Vavela the award for most beautiful coffee shop in Charlotte. I’d say this spot is most similar to Qahwah House in terms of size, and it shares the same beautiful, polished, upscale aesthetic that all the Middle Eastern coffee shops seem to have. The floors here literally glisten. 

One thing that stands out is the booth-style seating, with soft patterned fabric and pillows that make it easy to stay awhile and study, read, or work remotely. The cheesecake options are crazy in the best way possible. They don’t have cinnamon rolls, but they do sometimes have a cinnamon roll cheesecake, a revolutionary combination of pastry proportions I'd never imagined possible.

If you like any of the other Middle Eastern coffee spots, you should make your way here. It’s worth the drive no matter what side of town you’re on. Outlet access is solid if you grab a spot by the wall. Most of the seating is round tables in the center, so come with a full charge just in case. Parking is free in the shared garage behind the building.

Address: 13717 E Independence Blvd, Indian Trail, NC 28079
Description:
At Sugar Creek Coffee Roasters, we specialize in hand crafted, small batch, artisan roasted coffee. We don't roast your coffee beans until you place an order, so you can be assured the freshest roasted coffee is delivered to your door.
​
Located inside Sweet Union Brewing in Indian Trail, North Carolina, we're proud to support the local economy, as well as ship freshly roasted beans across the United States. We have a growing list of partnerships, including breweries and coffee shops, as well as several non-profit organizations that benefit from our support.

Address: 5904 Indian Trail Fairview Rd, Indian Trail, NC 28079
Description: Welcome to Psalms Coffee, your local cafe in Indian Trail, where we combine smalltown Christian values with delectable foods and beverages to deliver the ultimate coffee shop experience. As a family-owned coffee shop, we cordially invite you to stop by and treat yourself to some freshly-brewed coffee, healthy chai tea, thirst-quenching lemonade, or palate-pleasing frappuccino.
Comments:
Let me start by confessing my bias. I’m a devout Christian, so naturally I’m partial to this place. I love the Psalms and often turn to them as a way to enter into prayer. So when I walked in and saw the name, the concept, and the unapologetically Christian theme, I couldn’t help but love the place. 

There are Bible verses throughout the shop, a warm and inviting decor, and a wooden cross where you can leave a prayer or note on a post-it. I saw open Bibles on tables and overheard conversations about faith. Everything about this place resonated with me. To be clear though, it’s open to everyone. The owners just aren’t shy about their faith, which is exactly how it should be in a country founded in part on religious freedom.

It’s small, and especially popular on weekends, but for good reason. It’s new as of 2025 and already has a steady group of regulars. It’s miraculous I’ve talked this much and haven’t yet mentioned the fact that they have cinnamon rolls 🙌🏾🔥. Well sized, generously iced, filled with cinnamon goodness. They also have other pastries and cold drinks, along with a full coffee menu and a few tea options.

If you have kids, there’s a fenced-in play area right out front so you can sip coffee while your little ones run around without worry. It’s a thoughtfully designed coffee shop, unambiguous in its Christian mission and commitment to charity, kindness, and making all feel welcome. I love it.

Description: Finca Coffee is a coffee shop in the lobby of Eastgate Charlotte church. Our goal is to provide the best farm-to-cup experience and create a space in the community that has a relaxed vibe perfect for work, study or just catching up with friends.
Comments:
Very clean, bright, and modern. It’s inside a church that’s been around for a while, but the coffee shop is newer and pristine as a result. Nice place to get some work done. It’s well-lit, and they have those metal chairs with rounded legs and the skinny back support piece with a solid plate in the middle. The kind it seems every business in Charlotte uses. Functional, but not exactly cozy, so you won’t be dozing off.

I don’t drink coffee, even though I run a website that catalogs almost every single shop in Charlotte. So no comments there. But they have a few tea options, and they were sufficient.

Description: Sunflower Club is a gluten-free café offering fresh Belgian waffles, gourmet coffee, teas, and local baked goods. Enjoy art by local creatives while supporting outreach programs and wellness retreats through your visit. No membership required to dine, and both café and farm locations are available for event rentals.

Deli St is an innovative concept aiming to offer healthy quick meal options for young professionals and neighborhood residents that are always on the go. In a hip neighborhood full of diverse eateries, breweries and coffee shops Deli St draws the difference by baking their own goods, offering vegetarian and non-vegetarian options as well as a full coffee bar.
Comments:
If you're vegan or have vegan friends, you'll love this spot. Lots of great vegan sandwiches and health-conscious choices. They have a full menu with non-vegan options too, but it's all good. The Hangover breakfast sandwich is spectacular. It's a real meal, properly sized, worth the price, and will actually fill you up.

The aesthetic is very much deli. Not a ton of seating, most of it is bar-style, but there’s pretty decent access to outlets throughout. Not a bad place to plop down with a laptop and get some work done. They at least have high chairs with backs for the bar-style seating, which helps. Feels kind of hipster, in the best way possible. I grew up in Seattle. I like it.

Description: This cozy establishment offers an extensive menu of authentic bubble teas, Vietnamese coffee, and fresh bánh mì sandwiches.
Comments:
Very quiet in the evenings. I posted up here to get some work done on a random Tuesday, was nice. Small, indoor seating for 8 people, maybe 10 max, with a bit more outside. But there's Wi-Fi, food, coffee, pastries, and a lot of different bubble (or boba, whichever you prefer) tea options. Like, a lot. If that's your thing, you'll like this place.

They also have some board games available, so it's clear they welcome people to stay a while and relax. No one has ever recommended this place to me. I stumbled across it in one of my routine "type keywords into Google Maps and find random places" sessions, so I'd say it's a hidden gem.

Description: Sumaq is a cafe inspired by Quechua, the language and culture of indigenous South America. It serves craft coffee, matcha lattes, artisanal pastries, and fresh, made-from-scratch sandwiches with culturally inspired names, with both indoor seating and an outdoor patio for remote work or casual meetups.
Comments:
They have great plant work going on inside. The food is really good, particularly the breakfast flatbread and chicken/bacon sandwich, and the cheesecake, and the empanadas. All the food is good. And sometimes, usually in the winter, they sell pumpkin flavored cinnamon rolls 👀🔥.

The vibes are good as well. Bright aesthetic, wood colored tables and chairs with green accents here and there by way of plants. Very popular spot for friend groups to meet up. Also a hot spot among remote workers. And dates, always seems to be some love birds in here on weekends.

Outlet access is good, not great though, so I’d suggest coming charged up. In 2025 they added more seating, which is awesome because the only concern here before was it’s so cool it gets pretty packed. That’s less of a problem now, easier to find a seat.

Description: Specialty coffee shop, craft beer, wine cocktail bar as well as local pastries, free live music.
Comments:
A whole vibe. Laid back lounge aesthetic, dim lighting, upscale semi-rustic decor, suave jazzy music, quite nice. Lovely place to read a book or get some work done. Try the orange flavored cinnamon rolls. Also the cookies, courtesy of Honeybear Bake Shop. Both are splendid.

They also boast marvelous herbal tea options. Of the properly steeped loose leaf variety, none of that bagged nonsense.
