The Mémoire Citron Pressi, an oolong apple blend with heather and red cornflower blossoms, is quite good. Just look at the name. It can’t sound like that and not be some Grade A level stuff.

Description: ¡Descubre los auténticos sabores de Colombia en Roasted Tinto! Te invitamos a disfrutar de una experiencia gastronómica única que celebra las ricas tradiciones culinarias de Colombia. En nuestro establecimiento, ofrecemos una deliciosa selección de platos icónicos como arepas, empanadas, maduros, guacamole y mucho más. Cada bocado te transportará a la esencia de nuestra cultura y sazón. ¡Ven y déjate enamorar por la auténtica cocina colombiana!
Comments:
So, the descriptions for places on this site usually come from Google Maps. The fact that this one is in Spanish tells you all you need to know about its authenticity. I don’t even know what it says, but I spent a few hours here working remotely, and almost everyone who walked in was from Latin America and spoke with the staff in Spanish.

If you walk into a spot meant to represent a certain culture and it’s full of people just like you, not from that culture, then you're in the wrong place. It ain't authentic b. This place is the opposite of that. It’s the real deal. It's tucked inside a laundromat but has its own entrance and corner. It’s small but welcoming, with bright colors that reflect the Colombian heritage of the owners. There’s some outdoor seating if it gets crowded, though I haven’t seen that be a problem.

They’ve got great food, fresh pastries, snacks, cold drinks, coffee, and some limited tea options. The empanadas are solid. A true third place, full of life and cultural pride.

Description:
The Percantile and Creamery is the premier Coffee, Ice Cream, and Dessert Bar in the Charlotte metro area. We are thrilling people with our amazing interior design, our incredible customer service, and the quality of our offerings.

We have a beautifully designed 1920’s Mercantile-themed monochromatic throwback, where people feel excited by their surroundings, and blown away by their treats. Great for business meetings, families, couples, and you!
Comments:
Beautifully designed interior. Really beautiful art piece to your right on the wall as you walk in. Inviting atmosphere, there’s a seating area with a half wall that I love. Makes you feel nestled in, great for remote work or studying. They have excellent herbal tea options that they steep properly (no bags, loose leaf👏🏾), coffee, and all sorts of sweet treats, including ice cream and pastries.

But the topic of the utmost importance here is their cinnamon rolls. They’re a creamery in addition to a coffee shop, and some of that skill with sweetness has made its way to their cinnamon rolls. The icing (not cream cheese, which is good but harder to get right) is caked on top, in a way that provides enjoyment cold as well as warm. It’s not terribly large, not terribly wide, not terribly tall, not terribly small. It’s just right. Bravo.

If you’re looking for coffee or ice cream commentary, check the Google Maps reviews. People love both here, while I stick to herbal teas and cinnamon rolls. A man can only have so many vices. 

Lastly, if you’re super introverted or shy, they have an app and self-order kiosks where you can make your choice, sit down, and have it brought to you. I’m a software engineer by trade, so I love the tech integration.

Address: 363 Church St N Suite 100, Concord, NC 28025
Description:
Welcome to The Perc at The Nook, a café where caffeine and comfort harmonize. Nestled within the enchanting Percent Beer, our second location invites you to indulge in expertly crafted lattes, aromatic coffee, and a symphony of teas. 

While savoring your preferred beverage, dive into our delectable light bites, designed to complement our invigorating drinks. Our inviting ambiance extends both indoors and out, with ample seating, reliable Wi-Fi, and convenient parking. At The Perc at The Nook, we create a cozy refuge for you to unwind, gather, and enjoy the convergence of coffee and community.
Comments:
Plenty of seating, enough spots with outlets to feel relatively comfortable about being able to plug in if you’re coming to work or study. All the standard coffee shop options, but they stand out for their sweet treats, specifically the ice cream. It’s wonderful. 

Cool quirky aesthetic blended with upscale industrial chic vibes. Artwork from local musicians on the walls, Indie/alternative playlist, mismatching chair and pillow colors. It’s well designed for sure.

I’m sure the coffee is great, but I’m a tea guy, so I love that they properly steep their herbal teas here. Instead of the typical coffee shop routine of rushing hot water over a bag and calling it a day, this place opts for true tea tradition, steeping the leaves at the right temperature based on their type. 

White teas are best steeped around 160°F to 180°F for 2 to 4 minutes. Green teas shine at 175°F to 185°F for 1 to 3 minutes. Black teas need a hotter brew, closer to 200°F to 212°F for 3 to 5 minutes. They understand that here. Bravo to them. Waterbean is one of the few other places in Charlotte that does as well.

Description: Eatery offering gourmet sandwiches & artisanal baked goods, along with soups, omelets & pancakes.
Comments:
The first time I came here, the regulars were deep in conversation with a staff member, swapping life updates like old friends. One had been in a minor accident, another had just gotten a new car, and someone else was looking for debate on which wine to try next. Off in the corner, a guy was on his laptop, ostensibly getting some work done. That was it. I instantly pulled out my phone to add this place to the website. That’s a third place. Everyone felt at home, away from home.

The space is small, but there’s some outdoor seating that makes it reasonably comfortable on a warm day if you’re looking to plop down and hang out. Parking is on the surrounding residential streets. It’s free but can be sparse during peak times.

Bakery items, a full food menu, wine, cold drinks, and friendly staff. All the ingredients needed to settle in and stay awhile.

Description: Quaint cafe/bar in the McGill Rose Garden with hot drinks, craft beer & wines, plus photo sessions.
Comments:
Quaint, rustic, herbal, and full of character. It feels lived in and well loved, all adding up to a marvelously inviting place that I cannot recommend enough. It took me a few years of living in Charlotte and hearing people mention it before I finally made my way here, and I’m so glad I did.

This is top tier, 100 out of 10, for remote workers or students who feel stressed and need a spot where they can open a laptop, get some work done, then step away and relax. The McGill Rose Garden here provides just that. It's much larger than it looks from the road and gives you a forest-like, nature-filled oasis in the middle of one of Charlotte’s busiest neighborhoods.

The garden is the draw here. Don’t come just to sit inside. Bring a book, bring a friend, bring your dog. Show up early to beat the heat, or if it's not that hot, show up whenever. There is plenty of space to spread out and find your own quiet little corner.

It’s also a top tier date spot. The garden is large enough that, outside of peak weekend hours, you're likely to find a tucked-away space to sit together and have an intimate conversation. I went on a weekday morning and have never felt more at ease anywhere in Charlotte while working remotely. 

Indoor seating is limited, but if you show up early, you can usually get a spot. And every now and then, stand up, stretch your legs, and walk the garden paths. What a lovely place this is.

Description: Change Please is where social enterprise and coffee expertise blend. We train and employ people experiencing homelessness as baristas and put 100% of our profits towards giving our employees fair wage jobs, housing, therapy support, childcare, healthcare, onward job opportunities and more.
Comments:
Top tier spot for working outside. Great view of Uptown, most of the seating has shade, and there’s plenty of greenery. Very nice setup overall. It might be even better as a place to close the laptop and read a book. The vibes with the plants and shade and nice view are relaxing.

Indoors, it has an industrial chic feel, which is fitting because it is connected to an industrious operation called the Innovation Barn. There's plenty of space to sit. Not a ton of outlets, but there is a long strip in the center for people to huddle around if they need to plug in.

I don't drink coffee so I can't speak to the quality here, but they have herbal teas 💯. They're bagged but of a higher quality than your standard Bigelow bags. Most importantly, every dollar you spend here goes to help people experiencing homelessness. You can feel good about both the space and where your money is going. Be sure to walk around the larger building and check out the Innovation Barn. There is a lot of cool stuff going on inside.

Description:
Coffee by day, Jazz by night. Welcome to 88's, where sophistication meets rhythm in the heart of NoDa's newest development. By day we're an upscale coffee haven, offering a carefully curated selection of coffee to start your morning right. 

When the sun sets, we transform into a refined jazz bar, serving classics and favorites, while showcasing Charlottes best groove and blues artists. Named after the 88 keys on a piano, 88's is designed to capture the essence of timeless elegance and warm hospitality.

Specialty coffee shop offering a bistro menu, crafted gifts, wine room, & a bit of New England finds. Private & corporate catering options. We also boast a beautiful event space at the shop for corporate dinners, gatherings, baby showers, wedding rehearsal dinners, birthdays, and more.
Comments:
I'll start with what's most important. They have cinnamon rolls, and they are gargantuan. Colossal. Titanic, even. Not in height, but in circumference. I have never seen a cinnamon roll like it. Generously covered in cream cheese frosting and perfectly round. So very round. So very rotund. They’re made in house. They also make a variety of other sweet treats and serve food, coffee, and tea. 

As a place to hang out, work remotely, study, or meet up with friends, it’s top tier. Outlet access is solid in a corner with taller chairs, but what I like most is that the primary seating area has a wall that separates it from the rest of the store. There’s got to be some interior design principle that the TikTok feng shui guy would be able to name about why this works so well. It makes you feel cozy and comfortable, and it eliminates visual distractions. There could be 20 people in line and while you might hear them, you won’t see them, which really helps you feel nestled in.

The interior has a very cute, feminine aesthetic with bright colors and pink highlights here and there. They also have a cool-looking wine section and a larger table for groups. Solid spot all around.

Description: Daytime hangout serving a simple menu of pastries, sandwiches & coffee made using local ingredients.
Comments:
The food here is marvelous. Super small space, they limit Wi-Fi access on weekends, and in general ask that people limit their stays to 2 hours or less to free up seating. But I’ve found that on the choice weekdays they're open later, after 4 PM it's pretty quiet, so you can stay a bit longer. Solid evening study/work spot.

Very relaxed vibes. Kind of a Spanish villa aesthetic going on. I don’t drink but this feels like a place you’d drink wine at. Parking is limited out front but drive around the complex and you might find a spot. There’s a garage too nearby with some spots.

Description: Bitty & Beau’s Coffee is more than just a place to grab a cup of coffee — it’s an experience. The shop is run by people with disabilities and guests love the vibe — come see for yourself!
Comments:
Prime location in the heart of South End, with tons of interesting spots within walking distance. Outlet access is solid, Wi-Fi is strong, and they offer coffee, tea, pastries, and a covered outdoor patio that keeps the sun off.

I usually park at Atherton Mill (it's free) and bounce between this spot and Not Just Coffee. If one is crowded, I walk to the other, no need to move the car. It is a prime remote-work setup.

Check out their website for the story behind the business. Great mission, great values, friendly staff, and they have cinnamon rolls. 🔥💯

Description: Embedded in the Twenty Two West studio and storefront is our cozy Chai Window, where we serve up cups of beautifully spiced, rich organic tea made in house from whole spices, velvety oat milk, and softly sweetened with coconut sugar. Each sip adds a layer of warmth, creating a true sip and shop experience!
Bubble tea shop containing a variety of selections including hot/cold drinks, coffee & slushes.
Comments: If you’re a tea person, you’ll clock the smell of Oolong the moment you walk in. A lot of their cold drinks are also available hot and they clearly mark that on the menu with an H, which I appreciate. Also, it’s right next to Super G Mart, great Asian food/grocery store.

Address: 101 W Worthington Ave Suite 150, Charlotte, NC 28203
Description: Italian Bakery & Coffee serving Tiramisu, Sfogliatelle, Lobster Tail, Cannoli, Focaccia, Croissant, Eclair Gluten Free, Zeppole di San Giuseppe.
Comments:
Most of the seating here is outside. The interior is tiny, just a couch or two, but the outdoor tables sit along a narrow walkway that feels tucked away from the bustle of South End. Croissants are solid.

If you are coming from outside South End, aim for a warm day because you will probably be sitting outdoors. Bitty and Beau’s and Not Just Coffee are around the corner, so you can easily walk to either spot.

Pro tip, park in the Atherton Mill lot for free and walk over.

Description: Family-owned Ethiopian/Eritrean coffee shop bringing authentic East African coffee culture to Matthews. Known for homemade tiramisu, traditional coffee, a lineup of pastries, unique croissant sandwiches, and warm hospitality!
Comments:
New as of 2025. Some nice artwork on the walls, including Ethiopian and Eritrean-inspired pieces. The owners are very kind and welcoming. They even have a note on the window inviting remote workers to hang out for a while. Croissant sandwiches, excellent coffee (Ethiopia is the birthplace of coffee, so they know their stuff), tea, pastries (including cinnamon rolls 💯🙌), ice cream🍦, and snack items. They've got it all!

It is a smaller space, but it's well laid out. Good outlet access, and most seating runs along a wall, so you have something solid behind you. Sitting in the middle of foot traffic feels unsettling to me, so I appreciate that layout. There's even a little outdoor seating.

I volunteer with a nonprofit called the Carolina Youth Coalition (great organization, worth checking out if you're looking for volunteer opportunities), and many of the students are Ethiopian or Eritrean. If this spot were closer to them, I could see it becoming a popular after-school hangout. It's a true third place!

Description: Quaint little coffee shop offering craft and domestic beers on tap as well as in bottles and cans. Also offering wine and mimosas.

Address: 830 E King St, Kings Mountain, NC 28086
Description: Friendly neighborhood coffee shop serving quality coffee in a welcoming, community-focused space. Perfect for studying, catching up with friends, or relaxing on the wraparound porch. Everyone is always welcome!
Comments: If you're headed to Crowder's Mountain State Park for some hiking, definitely stop here as well. Quaint, homey spot, and they have cinnamon rolls!

Description: Cozy boutique coffee shop known for canned iced lattes and creative specialty drinks. Started as a coffee trailer, now a permanent spot in downtown Dallas. Friendly service, unique flavors, and free street parking. Welcoming local atmosphere for coffee lovers and friends.
We serve non-profit Colombian coffee, delicious pastries, artisan gelato, and grab & go food. Our focus is on outreach and serving the community.
Comments:
Calming, serene, clean vibes. Plenty of seating, and it’s spread out nicely. It doesn’t feel cramped at all. They make excellent use of what is a pretty large space for a coffee shop. Most of the seating is against a wall, so you’ve got something solid on one side to anchor you. There’s probably some kind of psychology behind how sitting with a wall nearby makes you feel safer, cozier, more nestled in. It’s newer and spotless as a result. Immaculate, really.

It’s inside Myers Park United Methodist Church, but it’s its own thing. Manolo’s is a Latin bakery in Charlotte, and this is their expansion into the coffee shop world. It’s their space, but it's clearly faith friendly and loved by the church.

Top tier spot to get some work done. They close in the early afternoon though, so plan accordingly. Seating is placed smartly with good access to outlets. There's artwork everywhere, and you’ll find outlets in most corners if you look. There’s also a long table down a hallway for group work and even a bookable conference room. Fast and free Wi-Fi. Gelato, pastries, coffee, and what makes me happiest, loose leaf herbal teas. Not bagged. Properly steeped. The Cherry Green is my favorite.

Parking can get tight during peak hours since it shares space with the church, but there’s overflow parking across the street. And a bonus, the Harris Teeter near here is two levels and has a huge patio on the second floor. It runs the length of the building and has plenty of seating and a wine bar. It’s popular with Myers Park soccer moms and book clubs, but I’ve posted up there solo to read a few times. A hidden gem.

Description:
Charlotte's most lush cocktail bar is now an all day cafe in the heart of South End. Start in the morning with coffee and espresso by local roaster Night Swim Coffee—plus flavored syrups and mushroom-based wellness shots—paired with savory and sweet breakfast bites by Built On Hospitality executive Chef Chris Coleman.

The Noon & Night menu features bold, craveable flavors for lunch, dinner, and everything in between (and after). Cocktail service begins at 10 a.m. on weekends and 2 p.m. on weekdays. Enjoy a Bob Peters creation with your brunch, afternoon calls, or when the workday is done. Reservations accepted and 21+ after 5pm, daily.
Comments:
Used to just be a cocktail bar, but expanded in 2025 into an all-day café. Breakfast, lunch, coffee and tea (from Night Swim), smoothies, alcohol, and more. Earthy, floral, elegant vibes. If you're into plants, you'll love this place. They're everywhere, and every single one is real. I went in the morning once to work, and a gardener came through to water them all.

It really is a beautiful space. Great natural lighting pours in through the roof windows, and on a sunny day, it looks gorgeous. The couches are super comfortable, and one of them sits right next to a stone platform with a constant little waterfall trickling through the plants. It's peaceful and makes the whole place feel alive. I really enjoyed working from here. It wasn't busy at all during the day, and access to outlets is outstanding, 10/10.

Right around the corner, you've got Wooden Robot and Babaloo Coffee Club in walking distance, both third places in their own right. PIE.ZAA is also right next door to this place, and they sell pizza by the slice. If you've had Zämbies or Benny Pennello's, it's similar to those, and pretty good.

Description: In the eclectic South End neighborhood, Babaloo Coffee Club invites you to indulge in a world of exquisite flavors. Step inside and be greeted by the rich aroma of freshly brewed coffee, enticing sandwiches, handcrafted empanadas, and delectable seasonal sweets. Unwind in a warm and inviting ambiance, perfect for catching up with friends. Babaloo Coffee Club is your go-to destination for a delightful sensory journey that celebrates the art of coffee
Comments:
I nearly introduced a "Tiny" sizing to this website after visiting this spot. It's beyond small, it's micro. There are quite literally two tables, totaling four seats, inside, with a handful more outside. If you're a morning person, this is a marvelous spot to bring a book, grab a coffee, and have your pick of the place before it gets busy. It feels closer to a grab-and-go stall than a place to hang out a while, but there is seating, it's just limited.

If you're waiting for me to comment about the quality of the coffee, I'm sorry. I'm not a coffee person. This website has just about every coffee shop in greater Charlotte and yet its creator does not drink coffee. I'm an herbal tea guy. Hot, specifically.

They had some tea options, Harney & Sons, which is about as good as it gets for bagged teas. I think the coffee is good though, because a lot of people told me to go here thinking I might enjoy it. I go to coffee shops for the vibes, the aesthetic, the atmosphere, the ambience. The coffee could be terrible and I'd be none the wiser, so long as I can nestle into a corner, flip open my laptop, and hang out.

Description: Vicente is a bakery and open kitchen where guests can watch pastries and breads made from scratch, blending science, artistry, and tradition. Inspired by Venezuelan, North American, and Buenos Aires roots, the menu offers globally inspired treats with familiar, comforting flavors.
Comments:
Small spot, maybe not ideal for an extended stay, but perfect for grabbing a bite or meeting a friend for a chat. There’s outdoor seating so on warm days finding a seat isn’t hard. There’s also Wi-Fi so you’re welcome to hangout a while if you want. Just be warned, inside it’s all high chairs, so not much back support.

But let’s talk about what’s most important at a bakery, the pastries. They're known for their croissants so definitely get one if you go. Then we have the focaccia or croissant breakfast sandwich, expensive ($11 when last I went), but good. All of that though is secondary to their cinnamon rolls. They call them coffee rolls, but I protest that label. Let’s dissect.

A coffee roll is basically a yeast doughnut ring that is fried, coated in a sugar glaze, and rarely holds much cinnamon. A true cinnamon roll is baked, shaped into a spiral with cinnamon-sugar folded between the layers, and usually finished with a cream cheese or vanilla icing. Completely different textures and flavor profile.

They’re similar enough that most people call them the same thing, but they’re different. What Vicente sells are cinnamon rolls. Both the icing and the cinnamon sugar are flavored with a hint of coffee (hit or miss on if you'll like this, I didn't), hence their decision to call it a coffee roll, but it's a cinnamon roll. Trust me on this, cinnamon rolls are my specialty. 

Finally, the staff here is very kind. A coworker of mine got into an accident right in front of the store, and they came out to check on them, made sure they were okay, and gave them a free box of pastries. Truly run by great people!

Description: Chief’s Modern Cocktail Parlor is a cocktail lounge in a historic NoDa mill home with beverages crafted by the one and only, Bob Peters. In the morning, we serve coffee and espresso, sourced from local Charlotte roaster, Night Swim Coffee, with light breakfast items from our sister restaurant, The Goodyear House.
Comments: Someone told me they host their book club here so I'd imagine it's a good spot for reading. I (the person who runs this website) don't drink, so I'm not often found at cocktail bars, but I've heard nothing but good things about this place. If you end up going contact me so I can update this comment with your take.

Place: The Holy Grind Coffee House of Kannapolis
Description: Our Kannapolis coffee shop offers customers a warm and relaxing atmosphere with uplifting music, along with quality coffees, smoothies, pastries, and more! It’s our passion to see people find rest, hope, and encouragement to make it through their day!

Place: The Holy Grind Coffee House of China Grove
Address: 819 S Main St, China Grove, NC 28023
Description:
The Holy Grind Coffee House is a cozy coffee shop dedicated to serving premium, ethically-sourced coffee in a welcoming, community-focused environment. Our expertly crafted beverages, from classic espresso drinks to innovative seasonal specialties, are paired with a selection of baked goods and healthy snacks. 

We blend faith, quality, and sustainability; striving to create a space where customers can enjoy both great coffee and meaningful connections. With free Wi-Fi, cozy seating, and a passion for fostering healthy communities, we cater to everyone—from students and remote workers to coffee enthusiasts.

Place: The Holy Grind Coffee House of Concord
Address: 587 Warren C Coleman Blvd, Concord, NC 28025
Description: Our Concord coffee shop offers customers a warm and relaxing atmosphere with uplifting music, along with quality coffees, smoothies, pastries, and more! It’s our passion to see people find rest, hope, and encouragement to make it through their day!

Address: 917 Central Ave Unit B, Charlotte, NC 28204
Description: Sip City Market & Bottle Shop is Charlotte’s go-to destination for craft beer, fine wine, and non-alcoholic beverages—plus a versatile event space perfect for private parties, birthday celebrations, bridal showers, game nights, and more. Located in the heart of the city, we offer build-your-own 6-packs, rotating beer and wine tastings, and a welcoming community vibe. Open late every night, Sip City combines a curated drink selection with a unique venue for unforgettable experiences.
Comments:
Daily Ritual Coffee is also in this same space. So, it just depends on when you go, whether it's Daily Ritual or Sip City, same building either way. 

The vibe is creative and cozy, like a mini art gallery, with paintings from local artists on the walls and various card games on the tables. Most of the seating is four-person tables, but there are comfy couches mixed in and a bit of outdoor seating.

Good outlet access, and good tea options, including pure Japanese matcha. It’s right across the street from Central Coffee, a Charlotte staple that’s fantastic but super small. If you’re in the area and need more space, this is a great alternative. Turn into the lot next to Two Scoops Creamery for parking, spots are limited though.

Address: 4732 Sharon Rd Suite M, Charlotte, NC 28210
Description: Upscale café and bakery featuring French desserts, pastries, coffee and tea. Custom cake orders and gourmet gifts.
Comments: Excellent presentation, small and cozy place, quite expensive though.

Address: 300 Technology Center Way Suite 200, Rock Hill, SC 29730
Description: Experience coffee like never before at Techno Café, where our robotic barista crafts premium espresso drinks with precision. Our stunning industrial space features soaring 20-foot columns, floor-to-ceiling windows, and multiple seating areas perfect for working, meeting, or relaxing. Enjoy locally-made pastries in our quiet, welcoming atmosphere. Free parking available in garage. Come see why we're Rock Hill's must-visit coffee destination!
Comments:
A fully automated coffee shop. No baristas, just robots making the drinks. My first reaction? That sounds soulless, heartless, anti-human. Like it's putting baristas out of work and killing one of the main reasons people go to coffee shops in the first place. The vibes, the human interaction, the sense of community that makes a third place feel alive. But the owners kept all the right things. Cozy interior design, a good amount of seating, and little nooks and corners to settle into. They just automated the barista and ordering part. It's still a warm, comfortable place to hang out. It's just that the drinks aren't "made with love" so much as they're "made with precision."

The shop sits inside the Rock Hill Event Center, which has a restaurant and all sorts of things going on, including the American Cornhole League Headquarters. Walk around the entire building if you visit. There's a very cool history of Rock Hill on display, including a model train set telling the story of the building before it became an event space. The whole thing makes for a great day trip from Charlotte.

The café itself isn't super huge, but every corner has seating and there's good access to outlets. It is a great spot for working remotely. There's a cute, artsy corner with half walls that's perfect for focusing. No hot tea from the machine, which is my thing, but all the coffee options are there. Pastries from local bakers (Wild Flour Sweets and The Daily Dough), snacks, and even store merch are available from vending machines.

I'm not a coffee person, so I can't speak to the quality of the brews, but everyone there seemed satisfied. Empire Pizza, right across from the building, is said to be pretty good too. If you're reading this, definitely check it out and form your own opinion.

Description: Join us for locally roasted coffee, cold brew, a full range of expert espresso beverages, and seasonal drinks! We serve fresh pastries, unique bagel creations, original cocktails, beer, and wine. Our coffee is roasted locally in Rock Hill, SC, and beans are available onsite or via our website for retail purchase. Visit our website for more information. Better yet, drop by to see us in person!
Comments: It's super small, but it’s in “The Alley at Latta Arcade”, a larger business building with seating lining the hallways, so there's spots to plop down and hangout. Not really a great location to work from, more like grab a coffee and read a book. The seating is mostly high chairs and tables, no outlet access. The cinnamon rolls they sell are incredible though.

Description: A neighborhood market located in the heart of the Arts District in NoDA, offering a casual atmosphere with pantry supplies and essentials, artisanal goods, grab n’ go sandwiches, a bar, and more. Led by Chef Kevin Samuel former executive chef of Bistro La Bon, The Exchange highlights the lighter side of culinary arts, offering a laid-back vibe and watering hole for neighbors and friends.
Comments: Cool, hip, bar with a market, food, and some seating meant for people to post up for a while. Have seen a few students studying here, and some remote workers. It’s around the corner from Waterbean NoDa, so another good option close by.

Description: Coffeehouse chain serving signature drinks, mochas & lattes, plus coffee & breakfast.
Comments:
Very small, seating for maybe 8ish people at max, and that'd be a stretch. Certainly not a place to go if you're looking to study/work and be guaranteed a spot. It's very nice though, a newer location with all the menu options that make Caribou an all-around better choice than Starbucks (to me at least). 

If you're in Monroe from Charlotte or one of the other surrounding areas, don't bother coming here. Go to August Lily Florist, High Octane Coffee, or Alice Jules Coffee House instead. All locally owned, all unique in their own ways, and all far more worthy of a visit in Monroe than Caribou, given it's status as a national chain.

Address: 8909 Lindholm Dr Ste C, Huntersville, NC 28078
Description: Coffeehouse chain serving signature drinks, mochas & lattes, plus coffee & breakfast.
Comments: Great access to outlets here, good place to post up and get some work done. Beautiful interior, the fireplace is a nice touch.

Description: Coffeehouse chain serving signature drinks, mochas & lattes, plus coffee & breakfast.

Since 2010, we’ve been serving great coffee in a warm, welcoming space where community comes first. More than just a coffee shop, we’re a gathering place where names, stories, and favorite drinks are remembered. Come to relax, connect, or simply enjoy a quality cup brewed with beans from around the world.
Comments: They have cinnamon rolls 💯🔥.

Description: Here at Waterbean Coffee, we always try to stay original and never follow the trends. In a time when most coffee shops focus on getting the customers in and out of their doors the quickest, we try to give them a place to relax, hold meetings, go over schoolwork, or just hang out with friends. We want to be more than just another coffee shop.

Here at Waterbean Coffee, we always try to stay original and never follow the trends. In a time when most coffee shops focus on getting the customers in and out of their doors the quickest, we try to give them a place to relax, hold meetings, go over schoolwork, or just hang out with friends. We want to be more than just another coffee shop.
Comments:
Waterbean Pineville has been my favorite of all their locations ever since it replaced Unwind Tea and Coffee. But this spot is giving it some real competition. The interior follows the Waterbean style guide: bright, clean, and energetic. White walls and faux marble tables. A mix of black and green velvet chairs with gold legs.

It feels like the café you'd find in the lobby of a tech or tech adjacent company, a look that matches the overall Waterbean aesthetic, as seen at their South End location at the base of LendingTree headquarters. Elegant yet approachable and perfect for getting work done. Outlet coverage is decent. The coffee bar has some tucked underneath for extra convenience.

The real standout is the rooftop patio. It seats around twenty, is strung with lights, has shaded corners, and plenty of open sky. If it's not too hot, it's a great place to post up and read, study, or chill. Many coffee shops have patios, few have rooftop ones!

Food/drink wise, I maintain that the Waterbean Special sandwich is one of the best in town. But their respect for tea remains why I love their locations. A magnetic display of tins lets you sample nearly twenty herbal blends by scent before you order. Temple of Heaven, Honeymilk Ginger, and Sweet Green Oolong are my favorites. 

As someone who runs a site cataloguing almost every coffee shop in Charlotte, it may surprise you to learn that I don't drink coffee. I'm a tea guy, and as such, respect any place that treats it with this much care. Bravo Waterbean, bravo.

Description: We're a specialty coffee shop, our primary emphasis lies in delivering exceptional, top-tier coffee of the highest quality.
Comments: This is in the bottom of a nice office building that houses Lending Tree among others. Small but very nice, has an upscale, elegant, feeling to it. The Waterbean Special sandwich is really good, as is their selection of herbal teas.

Description: Our vision for Waterbean Coffee is to create an environment where we are more than just another coffee shop. We’d love for you to think of us as an extension of your home or business. Whether you are simply grabbing a fast cup of coffee to go, having a meeting in our shop, going over schoolwork, or just hanging out, we want to be that place where everyone feels welcome.
Comments:
Very interesting location, it's right by a gas station, to the point where if you aren't paying attention, you might miss it. It looks like it might be the gas station's interior until you look up and see their sign. Parking is limited right in front of the store, and you can't park in the gas station spots, but there's more options behind the building and in the general area, all free.

Aside from that, if you've been to any Waterbean location, it shares that same polished white aesthetic, with darker accent colors on the chairs and decorations scattered about. Sort of like a modern doctor's office sort of thing going on. Or a cool and hip online bank that doesn't have brick and mortar stores and is trying to make finance cool, like Ally I guess. I mean all of that in a good way, I like the aesthetic here. 

What I like most though is the marvelous menu of loose leaf herbal teas they offer. Well over 20 options, green, white, oolong, herbal,, black, all sorts of custom blends. The Temple of Heaven herbal tea remains one of my favorites here.

It's a solid spot to plop down and study/work. I see student study groups here all the time. It's a small space but they pack it full of seating, and there's decent outlet to access if you sit in one of the 4-5 spots along the main wall. There's also a big table in the middle for groups and a few outdoor seating spots, so big enough to feel comfortable you'll find a spot.

Description: A slow moving Monday morning. A fast paced Wednesday lunch break. An easy and pleasant Saturday afternoon. No matter where you are in your week (or your day), you can count on Salted Melon to have exactly what you need, sometimes before you know you need it.
Comments:
Aesthetically, "it's giving" coastal brunch club. Playful umbrellas, cheerful signage, and plenty of windows, letting sunlight pour in and bounce off the bright colors. Very clean, curated, beachy sort of feel, featuring two outdoor patios that keep the theme going. It’s a solid spot to post up when the weathers nice.

They’ve got food, coffee, tea, drinks (the lemonade is pretty good), and pastries (no cinnamon rolls though 😔). Everything you need to hang out for a while and enjoy. It’s all pretty expensive though, so be warned. 

This is a really rich neighborhood. If you visit, walk around the shopping complex. It's nice, and there's a handful of high-end stores in the neighborhood. Restoration Hardware being one of them (which has a great rooftop restaurant if you're looking for a "we're taking things to the next level" date spot).

Description: Step into the world of CocoBean Coffee, where tradition meets innovation in every cup. From the heartwarming flavors of Milk Tea and the playful delight of Boba Tea to the deep, aromatic essence of our artisan Coffee and refined Tea selections, we've curated a menu to enchant every palate.

Get ready to experience the rich flavors of the Mediterranean! Anatolia Cafe & Cuisine brings you authentic Turkish and Mediterranean dishes, from savory kebabs to freshly baked pastries, paired with aromatic coffee and teas. We use only the finest ingredients to create a warm, inviting dining experience. We can’t wait to welcome you!
Comments:
Has a bright, polished aesthetic that feels modern and upscale without being cold. The entire space is lined with door-sized windows, letting in tons of natural light and giving everything a clean, airy vibe. The interior design blends deep blues, marble tabletops, patterned tile, and soft gray tones. Makes the space feel fresh and refined. There’s plenty of seating, with solid outlet access along the back wall and near the fire alarms by the windows, making it a good spot to get some work done. 

The Turkish food here is amazing. Specifically the Turkish pizza options are 🔥. Their bathrooms have mirrors with built-in lighting you can control with touch-sensitive buttons. Very cool. As for the name, Anatolia refers to the ancient region that makes up most of modern-day Turkey, a crossroads of civilizations, so it’s fitting that the space feels both timeless and stylish.

Description: Café offering coffee and a variety of matcha based drinks and treats.
Comments:
Stylish and a little bit eclectic, with marble tables, patterned tile floors, and distressed metal chairs that give it a vintage charm. Feels like someone aimed for elegance but wanted it to stay approachable and lived-in. It’s very small, so if you're aiming for a study/work spot, go early to grab a spot.

Matcha is a whole trend now, but traditionally, it’s just tea. Finely ground green tea powder whisked with hot water. Not sweet, not dressed up, just straight-up tea with enormous health benefits. I appreciate that this spot still lets you order it that way, even if you get a weird look for actually liking it. I'm a tea person, so I'm a fan of any spot that treats it with respect.

Address: 9826 Sandy Rock Pl A, Charlotte, NC 28277
Description: Your neighborhood bakery café serving delicious pastries; fresh-baked breads; stunning cakes; expertly brewed coffees and teas; and grab-n-go salads and sandwiches. We are happy to see you, and happier to serve you!
Comments:
If you’ve been to Tous les Jours, this is like that, but with more expansive food options. Shares a similar bright, modern aesthetic. There's a good amount of seating inside, with more outside.

If you're going here to study or work, go early. It gets pretty busy nearly every day of the week. That's likely because it's a bakery, so the earlier you go, the fresher the items. On weekends, it's packed. Families galore, line out the door.

The Wi-Fi is fast and free; there's a sign to the left of the checkout counter with the password. There are around 3-4 spots you can sit with outlet access, so not great, but not terrible. They have hot tea as well as other standard coffee shop drinks. The pastries are all fine. Nothing as transcendent as a cinnamon roll, but plenty of good stuff.

Address: 201 W South Main St # A, Waxhaw, NC 28173
Description: Holy Cannoli is your go-to spot in downtown Waxhaw for authentic Italian pastries and specialty coffee. Enjoy cannoli's, tiramisu, croissants, and more in a cozy, welcoming space filled with the scent of fresh espresso and baked treats. Whether you're stopping by for a quick bite or a relaxing break, our team is ready to serve up a taste of Italy.
Comments:
Clean, modern, and bright, with a light blue bubble gum aesthetic that’s very well executed. The sandwiches are great, especially the Vinny, and of course their main draw, the cannoli, lives up to the hype. What I appreciate most, though, is that they sell cinnamon rolls. They look and taste suspiciously like the Pillsbury ones from the grocery store, but honestly, no shame in that. They'll do.

They’ve also got a few hook and ring toss games on the tables. If you’ve never played, they’re surprisingly addictive. You think it should be simple, but after missing over and over, pride kicks in. Before you know it, you’ve lost half an hour trying to land that one perfect toss.

Anyways, this is a very nice spot, right in the heart of downtown Waxhaw. Within walking distance, you’ve got Jebena Cafe, Crossroads Coffee, and Provisions Waxhaw. All are great third places worth checking out, and together they make a day trip to Waxhaw totally worth it.

Description: Indulge in the rich, robust flavors of our premium Ethiopian coffee, a true delight for coffee aficionados and café enthusiasts alike. Each cup promises a vibrant taste journey that captivates your senses and awakens your palate. Whether you're starting your day or savoring a quiet moment, our Ethiopian coffee offers a truly unforgettable experience.
Comments:
In addition to food, pastries, drinks, tea, and standard coffee options, this place stands out for serving fresh Ethiopian coffee. If you’re into coffee, you should try it, Ethiopia is quite literally the birthplace of coffee. 

They have cinnamon rolls (💯🔥), and let you order them without icing, which is unique and a plus for those looking to indulge but skip a few calories. 

Very relaxed atmosphere. The space feels open, bright, modern, and clean, but not in that cookie-cutter, industrial-chic coffee shop way that’s become overdone. It’s got character of its own, with touches of Ethiopian culture throughout. 

Parking is a bit limited directly in front of the shop, but there’s free street parking nearby if you don’t mind a short walk.

Description: Coffee. Good coffee.
Comments:
It’s a cozy, cabin-style, charming house. Small but quaint. There’s a little seating section downstairs with a very cool jazz-inspired wall art piece, and a bit more space upstairs and out on the patio. 

It’s compact, as houses tend to be, but the vibe is welcoming. They’ve also got a gift shop and pastries. No cinnamon rolls, but the red velvet pound cake is 🔥. 

It’s located in downtown Waxhaw, a very walkable area with free parking and plenty of other spots worth visiting nearby. I recommend also stopping by Jebena Cafe and Holy Cannoli. Both are within walking distance. Definitely worth a day trip to Waxhaw.

Address: 107 W South Main St, Waxhaw, NC 28173
Description: Restaurant/retail shop with a coffee bar. We offer breakfast and lunch options from 7-3 daily. Retail items include local/regional suppliers of soaps, honey, lotions, olive oils & balsamic, pastries, and hand crafted gifts. We feature our lattes both hot and iced along with other specialty drinks.
Comments:
Bright and airy, plenty of space, and completely keeps that old-town storefront vibe. Wooden floors, tables, and chairs give it character in a way that feels intentional and comfortable, not outdated. 

It’s in the heart of downtown Waxhaw, right on the main walkway, so if you’re into people-watching, this is a great spot to post up with a coffee and watch the town stroll by.

But let me turn my focus to something of the utmost importance. They have cinnamon rolls, and they are divine. Cream cheese frosting that looks like the disheveled hair of a British rock star, chaotic and glorious in the best way. The roll is puff pastry-style, generously sized, and loaded with cinnamon. 

Overall, I like this place because it feels authentic and lived-in. They also have a general store and a full food menu, along with solid coffee, tea, and pastries. If you like small-town, locally-owned, down-to-earth, authentic vibes, a day trip to Waxhaw is worth it. For this spot, and a few others, including Crossroads Coffee, Holy Cannoli, Jebena Cafe, and Virtuoso Breadworks, all of which are within waking distance.

Cozy small town coffee shop vibes. Warm lighting, earthy-colored walls, and friendly staff. It’s a smaller space, but if you time your visit right, there are some good spots to nestle in and read, study, or just relax. They bake everything in house. The muffins are solid, cinnamon rolls show up from time to time, and the full food menu is worth a look. The chicken salad sandwich is especially good.

Description: When you make excellent hand crafted beverages, offer locally sourced pastries, brew Organic and Fair Trade coffee, offer live music, and engage in community ~ the world feels like a better place!
Comments: They have food, coffee, tea, live music, cinnamon rolls 🙌, and good vibes. Cabin meets industrial chic sort of aesthetic. It’s in a cute historic downtown area, so if you make the drive, definitely walk around.

Description: In its 20-year journey, Patisserie Cafe has evolved from the humble beginnings of Elsa and Manuel baking pastries and desserts in their home kitchen to become a beloved establishment. At Patisserie Cafe, we have realized the dream of providing a welcoming space where the community can gather to savor a delightful array of international cuisine and delectable pastries.
Comments: They have cinnamon rolls 💯🙌.

Address: 14231 Market Square Dr # C1, Huntersville, NC 28078
Description: B&K Tea Cafe is a cozy and vibrant cafe, known for its wide variety of bubble teas, specialty drinks, and light snacks. We pride our company on using high-quality ingredients and providing a welcoming environment for customers to relax, socialize, or work. B&K Tea Cafe is a favorite hangout for tea enthusiasts and those looking to try creative and refreshing beverages.

B&K Tea Cafe is a cozy and vibrant cafe, known for its wide variety of bubble teas, specialty drinks, and light snacks. We pride our company on using high-quality ingredients and providing a welcoming environment for customers to relax, socialize, or work. B&K Tea Cafe is a favorite hangout for tea enthusiasts and those looking to try creative and refreshing beverages.

B&K Tea Cafe is a cozy and vibrant cafe, known for its wide variety of bubble teas, specialty drinks, and light snacks. We pride our company on using high-quality ingredients and providing a welcoming environment for customers to relax, socialize, or work. B&K Tea Cafe is a favorite hangout for tea enthusiasts and those looking to try creative and refreshing beverages.
Comments:
I like that their booth-style seats have pillows so your back and butt don’t hurt after sitting a while. It’s not a huge space, but it’s just the right size to come with a group of friends. They’ve got board games, a claw machine, some snack and noodle options, strong Wi-Fi, and fun neon lighting touches throughout.

They don’t have hot tea options 😞, but the massive variety of iced teas more than makes up for it. There are so many combinations and types it’s almost overwhelming. I appreciate that they let you order everything without sugar, because they definitely will fill you full of it by default.

Description: A cafe serving great drinks and pastries in the heart of downtown Mooresville!
Comments: Quiet and relaxed space. Plenty of outlets.

Description: Summit Coffee's flagship store in downtown Davidson, North Carolina, this cafe serves coffee roasted locally by Summit, plus in-house baked goods, beer and wine and more.
Comments:
Very welcoming atmosphere. Plenty of seating, they have an upstairs area and a lot of outdoor space in addition to the main floor. Davidson is a college town so plenty of students and staff hangout here to study and work.

The aesthetic is down-to-earth, lived in, like a place that's been around for a while. I mean that in a good way, it doesn't have that pristine modern coffee shop vibe that's nice but a little plastic, it feels very homey. I think this might be the original Summit location, so that's why.

They have this birthday cake looking cookie where they put the frosting in the middle and don't spread it around. It's almost like they want you to eat your way to the frosting. It's a good cookie. Also they have a cinnamon roll that they call a "Big Bun". It's light on icing, but it is a cinnamon roll at it's core, so it counts. They have nice tea options in addition to coffee.

Address: 428 S Main St A, Davidson, NC 28036
Description: Here at Waterbean Coffee, we always try to stay original and never follow the trends. In a time when most coffee shops focus on getting the customers in and out of their doors the quickest, we try to give them a place to relax, hold meetings, go over schoolwork, or just hang out with friends. We want to be more than just another coffee shop.

Address: 605 Jetton St Suite B, Davidson, NC 28036
Description: Cozy, trendy coffee shop serving up caffeinated drinks such as lattes and cortados, plus desserts like croissants.
Comments: Small, modern, bright, place in a very walkable area with plenty of other businesses worth checking out nearby. Seating is pretty compact, but there's chairs and tables outside, and the Wi-Fi reaches out there, so you have options. Outlet access can be challenging when it's busy, so come charged up.

Description: Haraz honors our Yemeni heritage—home to the world’s first coffee culture—with beans grown at 3,000+ ft in the mountains of Haraz. As first-generation immigrants, we celebrate coffee’s power to bring people together through tradition and hospitality. Ask a team member for a validation code for up to 4 hours of free garage parking.
Comments:
Just as beautiful as the original Charlotte location in Elizabeth, but I give this one a leg up because it's bigger. There's plenty of seating. They've nailed this "modern but not cookie cutter" aesthetic that reflects the Yemeni culture behind the business. The coffee is good. I don’t even drink coffee, but I usually get something when I come here. The red tea is great too.

There’s free street parking, but it's all parallel and pretty limited. Official parking is in the garage owned by the South & Hollis apartment complex. The rates are ridiculous, and they don’t use ParkMobile, they’ve got their own thing. Haraz will validate, but personally, I’d rather park down the street than give some random parking company all my info. But that’s just me, data privacy nerd over here.

In can get packed here during peak times. There's apartments all around and the residents love this place. But if you're a remote worker, this is a chill spot on most weekdays. If you show up in the morning it's usually not that busy and you'll have plenty of seating spots to choose from. Outlet access is solid. The best seating to me is the light brown booth style seats in a corner near the wall with the Yemeni artwork. There's outlets underneath all the seats, padded backs, and a half wall thing with plants on top that block your view of the rest of the shop if you sit on a certain side. Makes you feel nestled in. 

This neighborhood, LoSo, has a lot going on now in terms of places to check out. Thousand Hills Coffee and The Everyday Market are right across the street, both great third places. And there’s a ton of other spots within walking distance. Plus, it's right on the train line, so if you live in South End, you don’t even have to drive to get here.

Description: Nestled inside Meck Church, the Grounds Bookstore and Café was founded in 2012. This unique destination seamlessly blends the love of books with the warmth of a coffeeshop, making it a tranquil space for people to come together. Whether you're working, meeting a friend, walking our nature trail, or reading, we have a spot for you to enjoy! Each purchase contributes to supporting worthy global and local missions and Meck ministries, making every visit a meaningful act of kindness that makes a profound difference.
Comments:
The space is huge, with a ground-floor bookstore, an upstairs loft with even more seating, and a sizeable outdoor patio that's great for reading with a view. If you’re looking for a place to work or study and want a guaranteed seat, this is the spot. 

It’s inside a church, but the entrance to the café is clearly marked and tucked off to the side, so you won’t accidentally wander into a service. And to take things over the top, they even have a walking trail called the "Meck Trail." Ask the staff where the entrance is. It’s thoughtfully designed with Bible verse signs placed along the path. Most of the trail is lined with trees and covered in gravel, so you get that peaceful outdoors vibe without dealing with mud. Since it’s a church bookstore, most of the books are Christian, which I love as a Christian myself. 

The café sells Honeybear Bake Shop pastries, who boast some of the best cinnamon rolls in Charlotte. They also have a solid tea selection, good coffee, and a friendly staff that’s always ready to help. Outlet access is decent. Downstairs is limited, but upstairs there are desks and tables with power strips nearby. Seating is a mix of leather chairs with metal frames, modern café-style chairs, and plenty of four-top tables. It feels like this place was built with intention. Not just a café or bookstore, but a true third place, somewhere you can linger, recharge, and feel welcomed. There’s just so much to like about it.

Description: Counter-serve bakery/cafe chain serving sandwiches, salads & more, known for its bread & free WiFi.

Bayt Al Mocha, a Yemeni coffeehouse brand from Michigan, is opening soon in NoDa at Centro NoDa (715 E 36th St). Expect traditional Yemeni coffee alongside modern espresso drinks, pastries, and retail beans. 

The company currently operates in Dearborn and Louisville and is expanding to Ann Arbor, Virginia, Rochester, and Marietta, per What Now Charlotte. Charlotte is slated for a fall 2025 opening according to the Charlotte Observer. Follow their Instagram for updates.

Address: 4701 Goose Crk Dr Ste B, Charlotte, NC 28269
Description: Summit Coffee is a neighborhood cafe creating moments of joy through good coffee, genuine hospitality, and a space built for community. We're serving up NC roasted coffee, tea and freshly baked pastries daily!
Comments: As is consistently the case across Summit Coffee locations, it’s a clean, modern, airy setup with great drinks and a welcoming atmosphere. This spot in particular gets great natural lighting from wall sized windows on the opposite ends of the building. There’s good access to outlets and enough seating to feel relatively confident that you’ll be able to snag a spot.

Place: Jade and Elise Obsidian Coffee Co.
Address: 7005 Wilkinson Blvd Apt D, Belmont, NC 28012
Description: We are a coffee shop that is in Belmont!
Comments:
This spot has a cozy, intimate vibe with a warm, wood-paneled aesthetic that feels straight out of someone’s home kitchen. It’s small, but charming. The seating is mostly arranged family-style with a central long table then several 4-top groupings. The parrot mural on the counter adds a fun pop of color, and the Colombian flag on the shelf is a nod to the owners' roots. 

They own a coffee farm in Colombia, and you can taste that connection in the coffee and pastries they serve. It’s not a spot to hunker down for hours and work, but it’s perfect for catching up with a friend or enjoying something sweet in a welcoming space. If you're in the area, it's worth a stop just for the warm energy alone.

Address: 9623 Red Stone Dr Suite 500, Indian Land, SC 29707
Description: Local chain serving coffee, tea & shakes, plus pastries & light eats, in a stylish, relaxed space.
Comments:
Marvelous outlet access, 10/10. Makes it a great spot to work from. It's similar to a Caribou Coffee in that they offer coffee, tea, great sandwiches, pastries, and a variety of other drinks. What sets them apart is the artwork. Local artists have pieces displayed on the walls that are available for sale, giving their work some well-deserved exposure. 

The space has a modern coffee shop aesthetic. Mostly metal or hard wooden chairs and faux marble tables. Clean, sleek, and businesslike. It's not particularly standout in terms of style, but it looks good and serves its purpose well. I wouldn't call it cozy, but it is comfortable, and that makes it ideal if you're looking for a place to study or get some work done.

Address: 153 E White St Unit B, Rock Hill, SC 29730
Description: The Jackass Café, Deli & Wine Bar is a café bar located in the back of The Mercantile HQ. Located in the historical Coca-Cola bottling building, The Jackass Café is full of our favorite local coffee, tea, wine & pastries. Visit our café in Rock Hill, SC today!
Comments:
This spot is attached to The Mercantile, a large general store with cool trinkets, gifts, and a folksy kind of vibe. Great food, wine, coffee, tea, and some pastry options. The aesthetic is artsy and earthy, full of personality. Definitely not your typical cookie-cutter modern coffee shop. Visiting here can easily turn into a whole day trip. It's within walking distance of Knowledge Perk, Rock Hill Coffee, Amelie's Rock Hill, and a bunch of local shops. 

When you're ready to wind down, head to nearby Fountain Park. Bring a book, grab a nice drink, and do some people watching. Plenty of Rock Hill date nights end up at this park. Or just read your book 😅. It feels like a scene straight out of a movie, the kind they always used to cast Drew Barrymore in.

Tags: Loose Leaf Tea,Hidden Gem,Great Date Spot
Description: Relationships and coffee go hand in hand. At CrossRidge Cafe, our love for people and our love for coffee will brighten your day. Come, let us serve you, and leave with a full heart!
Comments:
This place is part of the CrossRidge Center business park, but the café is open to the public. It's usually quiet unless there's an event, which makes it feel like a hidden gem. There's tons of seating, including recessed nooks, couches, bookshelves, and tables that give it a cozy, library-like vibe. Great spot to read or get focused work done without feeling like you're in the middle of everything. 

The café has a full food menu, Harney & Sons loose leaf tea, coffee, and cold drinks. No cinnamon rolls but they do have pastries and a cinnamon cheesecake that's 🔥. There's also a cool fountain with tall stone structures right behind the front desk you pass on the way in, making the whole place feel even more peaceful. And just a short walk away at Inspiration Ministries, there's a large park with fountains, ponds, seating, and waterside walkways that make this entire area feel like even more of a hidden gem.

Description: The Coffeeshop is a cozy, family-owned spot known for its high-quality coffee and welcoming vibe. We’ve partnered with Night Swim Roasters in Charlotte to bring you the freshest, locally roasted beans, and we offer a selection of delicious baked goods from The Bakery Shop in Huntersville. Whether you're grabbing a quick coffee, settling in to work with our free WiFi, or enjoying a snack, The Coffeeshop is the perfect place to relax and recharge.

Here at Your Mom's Donuts, we're not about ordinary. We aren't about a stale chocolate donut with sprinkles. We don't believe preservatives or artificial colors belong in donuts. We don't believe that donuts should be produced on an assembly line. We think every donut should be a masterpiece. We think supporting local farms is cool. We think bringing you donuts that are filled with quality ingredients is even cooler. We think words like "bliss" and "heavenly" should come to mind when you bite into one of our donuts. We think your mouth will agree.
Comments: They’ve got glorious cream cheese frosting cinnamon rolls, along with a solid lineup of donuts and coffee. The interior is modern, with fun donut-themed designs on the walls and a friendly staff to match. It’s less of a spot to work from and more of a place to read, catch up with friends, sip some coffee, and indulge in cinnamon rolls (the greatest of all pastries).

Address: 2012 Bridgemill Dr Suite 100, Indian Land, SC 29707
Description: Food, coffee, wine, beer, cocktails, mocktails and more! We have something for everyone!
Comments: Bright modern space with a very calming feel to it. They've got plenty of stuff, food, hot and cold drinks, alcohol, bagels, and croissants. They've got this honey butter croissant that's immaculate. You'll want to check your blood sugar after eating it, but it's marvelous. Great interior setup in terms of seating that feels tucked away. Excellent access to outlets inside, and they have plenty of outdoor seating, with a few spots out there even having outlet access.

Address: 2024 Bridgemill Dr Suite 112, Indian Land, SC 29707
Description: Teaplus is a boba tea shop originally founded in Boca Raton, Florida, known for its signature cheese foam—creamy, lightly sweet, and perfectly salted to complement their freshly brewed teas. Each drink is hand-crafted with high-quality ingredients for a rich, refreshing experience.
Comments:
Beautifully designed space, small but thoughtful. The floor looks cool. Not the boring industrial chic unfinished style that’s trendy these days, somebody actually wax finished the thing. Good for them. While it’s small, it’s right next to Rendezbrew, a favorite spot of mine with plenty of indoor and outdoor seating. So this complex as a whole is worth a visit. Very bubbly and social staff. More than willing to chat if you’re into that. 

They have a million cold tea options but also Asian food, the dumplings and ramen are good. And there’s some really cool anime action figures to the left of the counter. Super Saiyan 2 Goku, Super Saiyan Fusion Goku, God Fusion Goku, Goku Black’s Super Saiyan Rosé form, and various characters from Slam Dunk (the OG basketball anime, before Kuroko no Basket!). Huge anime fan here, respect to whoever set those up!

Address: 16709 Orchard Stone Run Ste300, Charlotte, NC 28277
Description: Tous les Jours means "every day"in French. Tous les Jours is a "French-Asian-inspired" bakery primarily serving a selection of baked goods and beverages.
Comments:
Small space with some extra seating outdoors. The indoor seating lines the main walkway, so everyone in the store ends up in your view. If you’re easily distracted by movement, you probably won’t love this layout, unless you grab a seat outside. 

If you’re planning to work or study, I’d only come on a warm day so you have that outdoor option if the inside fills up. Very pristine, modern aesthetic, mostly white with pops of color throughout. No cinnamon rolls, but a good variety of interesting pastries, plus solid coffee, tea, and other drinks. The hot pomegranate green tea is my go-to.

Description: Cakeable is a nonprofit café and bakery dedicated to empowering adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities through inclusive vocational training and meaningful employment opportunities. Interns develop valuable job skills, foster community connections, and create high-quality baked goods and café offerings. Cakeable proudly contributes to a joyfully inclusive Charlotte community where everyone can thrive.

Address: 413 Dalton Ave Suite B, Charlotte, NC 28206
Description: Award winning Craft Brewery and Taproom in North End Charlotte situated between Avid Exchange Music Factory, Camp North End, and Optimist Hall. Kid and Dog- friendly. Offering Craft Beer, Cider, Seltzer, Sours, Wines, Kombucha, CBD seltzers, and Snacks. Food Truck schedule posted weekly on Instagram. Family- Friendly. Open- air patio with Skyline views. Pub- style taproom welcoming to all, with secret room- a blend of library, speakeasy, church, cigar lounge, and dive bar. A hidden gem hiding in plain sight.
Comments:
This is my pick for the best brewery in Charlotte for reading. The whole aesthetic leans eclectic Victorian library, with dim lighting, antique sofas, couches, and lounge chairs. There’s even a bookcase with a hidden room behind it, which sometimes has a few pinball machines. I love the booth-style seats tucked behind the bar to the right when you first walk in. Super cozy nooks that are perfect for settling in with a book. 

They don’t serve food, but there’s usually a food truck parked outside offering solid options. Truly a standout in terms of personality amidst the crowded Charlotte brewery scene.

Address: APEX Southpark, 4425 Sharon Rd S120, Charlotte, NC 28211
Description: Welcome to Gourmand Market! Discover our extensive market filled with local gourmet delights. Indulge in specialty coffees and sip on exquisite cocktails at our full-service bar. Our grab-and-go menu features specialty coffees, cocktails, and local gourmet items, from soup to nuts. Enjoy frozen, hot, cold, prepped, or made-to-order breakfast, lunch, and dinner options.
Comments:
Very posh, ritzy, refined aesthetic. Black walls and furniture with gold, white, and gray accents throughout. It’s clearly designed to feel fancy, and the pricing reflects that. This place is unapologetically gourmet. There’s a coffee shop, pastries (including cinnamon rolls 🙏🏾🔥), bar, and market items. They have individually sold chilled Capri Suns, and I respect that. So it’s not entirely pretentious despite being upscale. 

There’s an upstairs area behind the bar, and that’s where most of the indoor seating is. It’s pretty cozy up there, mostly four-top tables and a few armchairs. The lighting is dim in a way that makes it feel calm and private, great spot to read a book or have a quiet meal away from a crowd. Downstairs, in addition to bar seating, there’s an outdoor patio with nice chairs. 

Parking is free on weekends, but since they share the garage with other businesses, you might have to pay depending on the day and time. Overall, a very fancy-feeling spot. It’s right next to Steak 48, a classic “we’re taking things to the next level” Charlotte date spot, so maybe swing through here after your next romantic outing.

Description: Backyard Brew is a family-owned and operated coffee and tea spot located in a house, in the historic district. We specialize in custom tailoring drinks to each person’s taste and wonderful customer experiences. Seeing you happy, makes us happy! We source and roast all of our ethically grown, organic coffee. We source and blend all of our own teas.
Comments:
If you’ve ever been to Brakeman’s in Matthews this is like that but within the city. It’s literally a home, so cozy, warm, friendly vibes to the max. The walls are covered in handwritten notes from customers over the years and drawings. You could spend a good hour just reading the walls and the stories that go with them. 

There’s limited parking behind the house but there’s a Harris Teeter across the street you can park at if it’s packed. Great cozy spot for remote work, especially on warm days as you can sit on their porch. And they have cinnamon rolls 🔥. Awesome, locally owned, down-to-earth place.

Description: A social destination featuring duckpin bowling, dozens of classic pinball machines & many more ‘old school’ entertainment options along with high-quality cocktails and crafts beers served daily. Come Play!
Comments: Really cool retro arcade games, small ball bowling, and old console games (Sega Genesis, Nintendo NES, Super NES, and 64, but no GameCube or original Xbox, those are retro these days!). The console and arcade games are free. The track and field game is my favorite, it’s pretty accurate with the times and distances (former collegiate track athlete here). Huge space, comfy couches, and a bar. Gets really busy on the weekends, overwhelmingly so. But during the week it's pretty chill.

Address: 500 W Trade St Suite 101, Charlotte, NC 28202
Description: Coffee Republic Trade Street is the perfect coffee shop near you for rich, handcrafted coffee and fresh bakery treats and sandwiches. Enjoy pastries in a cozy space built for community and connection. Visit the best coffee shop in town today!
Comments:
This spot has a great atmosphere for getting work done. It's cozy, but not in that countryside cabin, fall-asleep-with-a-book kind of way. It's more like, this chair is comfortable, the natural lighting (tall windows) is great, and I've got my own little corner to focus and be productive. Cozy with a buzz, not cozy with a nap.

Outlet access is solid if you sit at the coffee bar, and while it's a little more limited by the smaller two-person tables, there are enough spots where your charger can reach. So outlet access really isn't an issue here at all. The food is seriously good, especially for a coffee shop. The breakfast items and pastries are way better than you'd expect. And they have cinnamon rolls 🔥. 

The aesthetic is modern with an artsy twist; neon signs, art-adorned walls, and sleek finishes everywhere. It's a nice departure from the industrial chic style you see in most places. Very IG and TikTok friendly, but still warm and welcoming.

Very personal setting and vibe offering a great experience. The cafe is faith-based, black-owned, and truly loves engaging with customers. The red velvet frappé is a go to! (Comment from Samuel Blackmon, friend of the site creator.)

Description: The only home town coffee company in landis. We love serving good organic coffee. We serve a unique line of pastries and yummy gluten free options as well. Our best sellers are the Willowbrook latte, Vanilla Caramel Latte, and the Coffee United. Use our menu link to order online for an easy pick up on the go or sit and stay with us. Sip from our custom unique in house cups and shop our plant bar selections!!

Veni Vidi Vici is a welcoming café where fresh coffee, soothing teas, and delicious baked goods come together in a cozy, community-focused space. Whether you're meeting friends or enjoying a quiet moment, every sip and bite is crafted to brighten your day.
Comments:
The kind of spot that makes you feel at home the second you walk in. It's set in a converted house, cozy, super chill, and perfect whether you're getting work done, catching up with a friend, or just existing for a bit. The owner is incredibly welcoming, and you can tell he knows his regulars by name. The coffee hits (or so I've been told, I'm a tea drinker, and they have that as well), and the baked goods are fire. 

I haven't seen cinnamon rolls, but the range of pastries more than makes up for it. The banana nut bread and red velvet cookies are 🔥. They've also got fun drink options like the frozen hot chocolate and the Milky Way coffee if you're into sweet treats. Free Wi-Fi, soft lighting, mellow playlist, covered outdoor seating for hot summer days, and good vibes all around.

The aesthetic is very much "this used to be a factory." Wooden floors, brick walls, and loud and proud patriotism, definitely a great place to hit up on the Fourth of July. They don't have actual cinnamon rolls, but they do have a cinnamon roll-inspired coffee, which some folks (not me) might argue is even better. Most of the seating is at high tables, with a few spots by the window. There's not a ton of indoor seating, but plenty outside, so on warm days that's no issue. 

Outlet access indoors is excellent. It's right in the heart of downtown Kannapolis, surrounded by cool shops and local attractions. Great date spot. You can walk over to The Spice and Tea Exchange, one of my favorite places in the region for every kind of herbal tea imaginable (I'm a tea person). 

There's also a ballpark nearby if you're into baseball, or you can just stroll the row of shops outside. A great hangout if you're tired of Charlotte's "everything is new and pristine and nothing feels lived in" aesthetic. Downtown Kannapolis still has that small-town, mom-and-pop charm, and I love that.

Description:
Editions Coffee Shop & Bookstore is a cozy haven where literature and caffeine connoisseurs come together. As you step inside, the aroma of freshly brewed coffee mingles with the scent of well-loved books, creating an inviting atmosphere that sparks creativity and relaxation.

The space is adorned with shelves stacked high with a curated selection of both new releases and timeless classics, inviting patrons to explore literary worlds while savoring a cup of their favorite brew. You can also find a selection of gently used books!

The coffee offerings are equally enticing, with expertly crafted espresso drinks, teas, and Lotus Energy drinks!
Comments:
I love this place. It's exactly what the name suggests, a coffee shop and a bookstore, but inside a converted house. I already love libraries and bookstores in general, but this one adds a full coffee shop while still keeping that traditional bookstore vibe, not the chic, trendy setup you get at Barnes & Noble these days. 

You'll see writing groups meeting to share their latest work, book clubs gathering, friends chatting, students doing homework, and people on their own reading, working, or browsing the shelves. I wish I lived closer so I could go more often. 

There's great access to outlets at the seating spots near the windows, and they even put sticky notes with the Wi-Fi info nearby, which I appreciate. There's a certain seat where you can see the road to your left and the train tracks to your right, so you can watch cars and trains go by. Main character, "my life is a movie" energy. 

Books are everywhere. They've made smart use of the space. Even when it's busy, if you peek around, you can usually find a place to sit. And while it's a coffee shop, they have an expansive tea menu. They've got a whole range of flavors, hot or cold. The respect for tea lovers is real 👏🏾💯. 

If you've ever been to Brakeman's in Matthews or Backyard Brew in Dilworth, also coffee shops in converted homes, it's like that but bigger and with a bookstore. There's plenty of parking, but just a heads-up, the entrance is a bit up the road across from the church. The road in front of the store that looks like the entrance is actually the exit.

Description: French Express Coffee House offers a variety of coffee, smoothies, and pastries. Known for its friendly staff and cozy atmosphere, it also features a convenient drive-thru. A local favorite for quality drinks and a welcoming environment.
Comments: Very friendly staff and a cozy, quaint, and inviting atmosphere. The concrete floors, corrugated metal paneling, and visible brewing setup give it a working, functional, industrial DIY sort of vibe. It's a smaller spot with just a handful of seating options, including a few four-person tables, some sofas, and a row of high chairs along a table by the window. Dog-friendly and has a drive-thru, which is a nice bonus.

Description: Lively indoor market hosting local shops, bars, bakeries & a variety of counter-serve eateries.
Comments:
This spot includes a Not Just Coffee, Resident Culture, free Wi-Fi, plenty of seating, and lots of cool food stalls. It has an industrial chic vibe and is super trendy, from the decor to the music. The space is large and open, with all the seating positioned centrally while people walk about on both sides. That layout gives it an energetic feel, but not a relaxing one. Definitely not cozy. 

If you're easily distracted by movement, this might not be the spot for you, as there's nowhere to sit without people constantly walking by in your view. But if you like people watching, you'll love it here. Geno D's Pizza is great, and the overall setup is ideal for groups. Most of the seating is at large tables built for six or more, so it's a perfect hangout spot if you're rolling deep. And if you're not staying long, they have free 2-hour validated parking.

Description: A unique coffee shop nestled within a historic funeral home, offering a cozy atmosphere with a variety of specialty drinks and baked goods.
Comments:
Concrete floors, metal chairs, exposed lighting, and corrugated metal along the counter give this place a distinct urban industrial vibe. It's a small spot, just a few tables inside and a couple more outside, but what makes it unique is that it's attached to a funeral home. 

The name "Coffin House" is quite literal. I felt surprisingly cozy here. Genuinely at ease. I don't know if it's a spiritual kind of calm that comes from being next to a funeral home, like that quiet stillness before death, which might actually be a little concerning if that's the case, or if it's just the warm decor and kind staff. Either way, this is a cool spot worth visiting.

Description: At Mattie Ruth’s our mission is for every individual who walks in both new and regular customers, to leave as happy with their experience as they are with their coffee. We strive to make the space and community just as important as the coffee.
Comments:
Has a rustic cabin aesthetic, down to the scent, coffee mixed with a woodsy aroma that feels warm and authentic. Wooden chairs, cowhide rugs, plenty of art on the walls, Bohemian vibes, and reading lamps scattered across tables. Someone put real care into this space, and it shows.

More than anything, though, I have to praise the cinnamon rolls they get from Honeybear Bake Shop in Charlotte. They have cream cheese frosting with a hint of maple flavor that seeps perfectly into the roll. As a self-proclaimed cinnamon roll connoisseur, it's fantastic. The sheer size combined with the standout frosting puts it on another level. Cream cheese frosting is famously difficult to get right on cinnamon rolls, so the quality of this one is all the more impressive. Until the day I had this cinnamon roll, I was convinced Sunflour Bakery had the best in greater Charlotte. Now I’m in doubt. Honeybear Bake Shop is serious business, and Mattie Ruth’s is blessed for carrying their rolls. 

This is a cool area in general. Gibson Mill Market is right across the street, which is similar to Optimist Hall but with a more relaxed "friends and family" vibe rather than the increasingly crowded, pretentious, "we have a huge lot, but you have to pay for parking now," trendy TikTok influencer vibe that Optimist has drifted toward 😞.

Address: 1115 Old Charlotte Rd SW, Concord, NC 28027
Description: Craft Coffee House with a mission to create an inclusive, community serving environment.
