Address: 7201 Matthews-Mint Hill Rd, Mint Hill, NC 28227
Description:
Coffee shop by day and wine bar vibes at night. Check us out for natural wines, local craft beers, and a selection of handmade cocktails, as well as, light far served from open to close. We have a small but excellent selection of wines to go as well. With the largest selection of natural wines in Mint Hill.

Whether your thing is coffee, tea, boba, fresh hand-squeezed lemonade, beer, wine or anything in between this is the place to go for absolutely delicious beverages all day long.
Comments:
Sits in a converted house with plenty of seating across the indoor and outdoor areas. It’s a similar vibe to Brakeman’s in Matthews. Has that homey community gathering spot feel, in part because it’s literally in a home, but also because they host plenty of events and gatherings for various groups in the area. 

Customers and staff alike look very relaxed, at home even, here. There’s sufficient spots near outlets for remote workers and plenty of parking behind the house. They have cinnamon rolls, not the cute bite sized kind, proper fully formed cream cheese frosting cinnamon rolls, and they are sublime.

Address: 14825 Ballantyne Village Way Suite 135, Charlotte, NC 28277
Description: Coffee Republic in Ballantyne Village is the best coffee shop near you! Enjoy artisanal coffee, fresh pastries, and a welcoming ambiance. Whether grabbing a quick cup or relaxing with friends, our café is your go-to spot for quality coffee and treats.
Comments:
Lots of food and pastry options that all look great, including cinnamon rolls from time to time. But not a ton of comfortable seating options. Downstairs is all high-top bar-style seating with your back facing the entrance and checkout area, so everyone coming in is walking directly behind you. The TikTok feng shui guy would say that’s not good design.

There’s an upstairs area too, but it’s super compact. A big table, a couch, and some smaller tables and chairs are all squeezed in tightly. If you go early and claim a good seat, it could work as a place to get things done. But if not, I wouldn’t call it cozy or comfortable.

If you come here to work or study and can't find a spot, whip around the corner to Panera Bread. It’s big and you’ll almost definitely find seating. Sunflour Bakery (my favorite of all their locations), Summit Coffee, and Starbucks are all nearby too. Ballantyne has its own little third place thing going on.

Description:
Serving the community of Ballantyne with locally owned craft coffee, homemade pastries, beer, and wine! 🥐☕️🩵
#findyoursummit
Comments: Small but charming.

Place: Starbucks | 135 Levine Avenue of the Arts
Address: Duke Energy Center, 135 Levine Avenue of the Arts, Charlotte, NC 28202
Description: Seattle-based coffeehouse chain known for its signature roasts, light bites and WiFi availability.
Tous les Jours means "every day"in French. Tous les Jours is a "French-Asian-inspired" bakery primarily serving a selection of baked goods and beverages.
Comments: Small but connected indoors to SipCha Bubble Tea, so you have more drinks and seating options. Friendly staff.

Description: We were the first specialty coffee shop in Lake Norman and are now expanding to Belmont. Our goal is to create a space where you can have business meetings, study, hang out, or simply grab a quick cup of coffee to-go. We aim to be your home away from home.

Wake is an exclusive, yet inclusive Coffee & Champagne Bar. Specialty drinks and cocktails are served with style and finesse. Whether you're here for an intimate date or with a group of friends our staff will serve you with hospitality and excellence, The Wake Way.

Our staff is well qualified in the techniques and quality ingredients used to create our crafted drinks, coffee and cocktails. Enjoy an afternoon or evening of charcuterie, high end pastries with your choice of coffee, champagne, wine, or beer. Our vision was to create an exclusive experience for our community through hospitality while highlighting Charlotte's hidden gem, Mtn. Island Lake.
Comments:
Small space but they make good use of it to fit seating. They have small cubicle style areas near the back where you can work/study, but they’re paid spaces. So paid mini co-working spaces, can’t just pop into one. But they also have limited general seating in the front of the store that’s open to all. They have coffee, tea, treats (ice cream, pastries), and a bar. 

They have cinnamon rolls that they get from Sam’s club, cream cheese frosting. I know this because I’m plugged into the cinnamon roll scene of greater Charlotte. It’s something of an area of expertise for me. They’re marvelous cinnamon rolls, better warm, but amazing regardless. They’ve got some unique tea options, sourced locally.

Description:
The country of Yemen is unapparelled to any other place on this Earth. From its breathtaking scenery to its history that dates back to the beginning of man. Yemen is the homeland of our family. As first-generation immigrants, we wanted to honor our heritage.

Yemen is where coffee was invented and later flourished in global trade. Roasting and serving coffee is something that is inclusive of all people and cultures, and brings people together. Our coffee is grown from altitudes over 3,000 ft in a mountainous village called Haraz, where our namesake originates.
Comments: Immaculate vibes. One of the few places open later so if you need to really get some work done or study, this is a good place to hangout. Very popular date spot though, so it can be tough to find a space to sit if you go during peak hours. There’s two parking options: behind the store and across the street on Hawthorne (behind 1124 Central Ave).

Comments: The SouthPark location is one of my favorite spots in the city, but this one is alright. Small but serviceable.
This is inside a larger office/retail building that has plenty of seating in the lobby area. If you go in the morning, get the French Toast, it’s good.

Comments: Good access to outlets, deli style food, convenience store, coffee and tea, bar, solid amount of seating indoors and outdoors. Great spot. Parking is free, there's more in the garage behind the building if you can't find something right in front. The SouthPark location is still my favorite, but there's no bad Rhino Market!

Description: A modern and welcoming coffee shop in Steele Creek serving up specialty coffee drinks, scratch-made sandwiches, salads, and pastries. Javesca exists to be a catalyst for change in the coffee community by giving a portion of our gross revenue back to feeding and community transformation initiatives in the United States and abroad through our sister Non-Profit Javesca Feeds. Indoor Playground available as part of Steele Creek Community Center.

Sunflour Baking Company is the Charlotte bakery & cafe you have been looking for! Come visit our five locations to get a taste of our fresh brewed coffee or small batch, homemade pastries and breads.Since 2009, Sunflour Baking Company has been a local favorite in the Noda neighborhood as well as for customers all around Charlotte and beyond. People all over the country order our Cake Jars every day!We invite you to come to visit our local cafes. They are all great spots to hang out, get work done, catch up with friends or enjoy some quiet time. We are sure you will love our bright, friendly interiors and of course our pastry case.
Comments: They have what I consider to be the best cinnamon rolls in Charlotte. I suggest getting two, eat one right away, and save the other for eating at home after warming it up. As a general rule, I’d encourage you to refrain from offering your opinion about a cinnamon roll until you’ve had it both cold and warm. Things can taste rather different heated up, flavors coming out, for better or worse. They can sell out of cinnamon rolls pretty quickly sometimes though, if you show up after like 11 AM, no guarantees. The sandwiches are also pretty good. Be warned though, the whole menu is expensive. Like, I’ll go in here and buy 2 things and get asked for $28 and be just flabbergasted. But the cinnamon rolls, they wash it all away. So it’s worth it. The gigantic rice krispy treat they have sometimes also slaps.

Description: This cheerful gathering place draws a crowd for its pastries, light fare & coffee drinks.
Comments: This place is huge. You have the entry level with plenty of seating, but also an upstairs that can easily seat 30 people and a downstairs (that’s sometimes blocked off for private events) that can fit a good chunk of people as well. The only thing about Uptown is if you're driving, you'll have to pay for parking. But if you're on the rail trail or walking distance, definitely make the trek over here.

Description: Stylish coffee bar offering pour-overs, cold brew & espresso, tea, food, and baked goods.
Comments: This is in Camp North End, parking is free in the large lot back  . They have some really fancy named teas and they’re all incredible. If you get it “for here”, they give you a nice cup and this fancy kettle pot thing to pour it from. The food is good, they give you a lot of it for the price. It’s not small cute coffee shop meals, it’s a full restaurant style plate of food. They have orange flavored cinnamon rolls sometimes 🔥💯. Lots of windows, gives the place a bright and energetic feel. Excellent access to outlets as well. Great music playlist, good vibes. Awesome day trip for remote workers, Camp North End has a lot to explore. Start at Hex, walk around after work, and end at Heist Brewery. Solid day.

Description: Deli sandwiches, breakfast sandwiches, coffee, fine wine, craft beer
Comments: Great spot to work from during the day. Only gets crowded during lunch, but even then there's a lot of seating indoors and outdoors so you can almost always find a spot. Tea, coffee, deli, and a convenience store inside. S-tier remote work spot. Everything you need is there. It becomes a bar in the evenings (or early afternoon for the day drinkers). If you sit at the bar, there’s outlets underneath the table. They're open until 9 or 10 PM most days.

Comments: A Charlotte staple. Parking is free for only the first 1.5 hours. It's a hall with a lot of businesses and plenty of seating, although most seating is not situated near outlets. It gets loud here, so not great if you're looking for a cozy laid back vibe, but great if you're looking for some energy.

Comments: They have what I consider to be the best cinnamon rolls in Charlotte. I suggest getting two, eat one right away, and save the other for eating at home after warming it up. The gigantic rice krispy treat they have sometimes also slaps.

Comments: Small but it always smells really good in here. There’s some cool abstract art on the walls. Limited parking right behind the building.

Description: Stylish cafe for gourmet coffee, sandwiches & pastries in a chic space with lots of seating options.
Comments:
The indoors is connected to a hotel which has additional seating if it’s crowded in the main area. Great vibes here. Plenty of remote workers huddled inside. It's a common recommendation among remote workers and students in Charlotte for good reason. The vibes. The vibes are A+. 

They have cronuts, and sometimes cinnamon rolls 🔥. The only thing is, it's in Uptown, so you're paying for parking if you drive. Worth it though, at least once to check it out. The upstairs area above the stadium style seating has some excellent tucked away spots, great for feeling cozy, and outlet access excellent all throughout the store. 

You can sit in the hotel as well if need be. It’s one of Charlotte’s best coffee shops in terms of space, vibes, aesthetic, and convenience for students and remote workers wanting to stay a while. They even have some bigger tables for groups, so your book club can hang here too.

Description: This funky store with a variety of goods houses an all-day eatery & deli with a bar & live music.
Comments:
Plenty of seating, both indoors and in a covered outdoor section, great sandwiches, coffee, a bar, various convenience store offerings. Eclectic, punk sort of vibes in terms of aesthetic. Feels lived in, authentic. You'll see plenty of remote workers on their laptops during the day. 

When you make a deli order, they ask your name then announce it over a loudspeaker when its ready. Gave me grade school nostalgia, being called to the office. Good luck if you have a tough name, I use a simplified version of mine to avoid embarrassment. The biggest challenge here is outlet access, so come charged up.

Description: Popular spot offering draft brews & deli sandwiches amid a convenience store, plus outdoor seating.
Comments: Indoor seating is mostly bar style, high chairs, but there's additional outdoors. Great spot for a warm day. Convenience store, deli, bar, coffee, and really cool punk/alt vibes. The convenience store has a wider selection of random snacks and drinks than a gas station typically would have, which I appreciate. Parking is free behind the store but limited, especially during peak hours.

Description: Popular spot offering draft brews & deli sandwiches amid a convenience store, plus outdoor seating.
Comments:
This place is spacious, with indoor and outdoor seating on the main floor, plus an upstairs area with more seating and a small patio. Very alt-punk/rock aesthetic, which I personally love since I grew up in Seattle. It feels like the kind of spot the crew from a 2000s coming-of-age film (the ones who get bullied by the popular kids and listen to Radiohead, Dashboard Confessional, Mayday Parade, My Chemical Romance,  Boys Like Girls, All Time Low, and Yellowcard) would hang out at, talking through their trauma and how much they want to "get out of this town." 

And I mean that in the best way possible (I may have just listed some of my favorite bands). This place is awesome. The sandwiches are great. The music is on point. I don’t even bother with headphones unless it’s packed. Truly a standout when it comes to vibes. I'm surprised it's not busier, I consider it a hidden gem in South End. There's a lunch crowd, but outside of that on weekdays during work hours it's pretty chill. 

For remote work, there’s some access to outlets upstairs, and 1-2 downstairs by the vending machine, but not a lot overall, so come charged up. If you’re a morning person, you can practically have the whole place to yourself if you show up early. It doesn’t get busy until the afternoon. The outdoor seating is also great and plentiful.

Parking is the biggest challenge here. There’s free parking near the store, but it’s limited. Street parking and nearby lots are options, though not always free. South End is designed for walking and light rail access, which is great unless you’re coming from another neighborhood and need your car. Not complaining though, just making a note.

Outstanding, truly fantastic, access to outlets here. Bravo to whoever designed the space, with a nice bright, clean, aesthetic as well. Great tea options. Try the Qi Dan Red Robe Oolong if you want to expand your palette. I know it's a coffee shop, but I'm a tea person, so as you read my comments on this site, that's what you'll see me reviewing drink wise. Parking is free in the angled spots in front of the store but time limited (2 hours). There's paid lots in the area if you want to stay a while. There's a Common Market within walking distance, great spot for lunch, and also to hangout when it's warm outside, plenty of outdoor seating.

Comments: I think Panera is overpriced and the food is middling at best but the interior set up and organization as a place to read, study, or work remotely remains excellent across most all their locations, this one included. Also, they have cinnamon rolls, and they’re quite alright. Nothing remarkable, but certainly passable.

Place: Night Swim Coffee | One Wells Fargo
Address: 301 S College St Suite 2810, Charlotte, NC 28202
Description: Specialty coffee shop from a local Charlotte roaster serving carefully crafted espresso drinks, drip coffee, and rotating single origin offerings, along with a small selection of pastries. Known for consistent quality, attention to detail, and baristas who can help you choose something new, it is a reliable stop whether you are grabbing a quick coffee or exploring more adventurous seasonal drinks.
Comments: I consider this spot a hidden gem. The seating is outside the coffee shop in a general atrium sort of area for the whole building, and there's plenty of it. You have to walk around the corner to the hallway adjacent to the YMCA to see all of it. Good view of Uptown, great lighting from big windows. Yeah. Great spot. It's Uptown though, so if you're driving, you'll have to pay for parking.

Description: Relaxed spot serving high-end coffee drinks, plus tea & light fare in an airy space with a patio.
Contemporary spot serving high-end coffee drinks, plus tea & light fare like toasts & yogurt.
Comments: This is inside The Market at 7th Street so you have the whole building as your third place while you're there. Plenty of food and cool stores within the building.

Comments: Large, spread out, airy interior.

Popular gathering place for craft coffee drinks & tea with outdoor seating on the front lawn.
Comments: Sits in a converted home, very cozy, very welcoming, very warm, very, dare I say, demure? Between outdoors, the first floor of the house, and the upstairs area, there's a good amount of seating. The parking situation however can be challenging during peak times. There's about 6-8 spots right behind the shop and a handful more directly in front. Great atmosphere for working remotely, meeting friends, or just vibing. It's everything a third place is supposed to be. Coffee and tea is great, and they have great pastries as well. Awesome spot!

Tags: Black Owned,Loose Leaf Tea,Great Date Spot
Description: Come unplug, relax, and experience a cup of serenity at the Pauline Tea-Bar Apothecary! Sip or purchase an herbal tea, spend time in contemplative solace, or experience creative play with a friend or group! Also register for one of our holistic classes and gain greater clarity or nourishment for your soul!
Comments: I'm a tea person, so I love this place. I wouldn't go here to work because I feel like with how cool the vibe is, it's better to not think about work here. Sip tea, read a good book, chill out. Lovely place!

Description: Greek bakery featuring a variety of treats and a relaxed, friendly atmosphere.

Comments: Whole Foods are already by nature fancy stores, this is among the fanciest I've ever seen. The patio upstairs is super nice. They have turf lining the ground. Turf. Like the kind on football fields. It's a great spot for studying/working because of the upstairs section where you can get away from the visual distractions of the store below. Amazon bought Whole Foods all those years ago and have done quite well with it. Bravo.

Comments:
Right next to a Whole Foods, Starbucks, and Panera Bread, so you’ve got plenty of options within walking distance. They’re a bit strict about lingering. The Wi-Fi cuts off after about an hour if you don’t make another purchase. 

I totally get having a policy like that. If you’re going to hang out for a while, it’s fair to keep supporting the business. But the short time window and sudden cutoff make it feel more like a grab-your-drink-and-go spot than a place to nestle in and feel cozy or welcomed.

Description: Coffeehouse chain serving signature drinks, mochas & lattes, plus coffee & breakfast.
Comments: A favorite study spot for students in the area. Not a ton of space, but what they have, they use well. Caribou has an extra large size for hot drinks that's beyond the Starbucks venti. For that alone, I prefer their locations. Also the sandwiches are better.

Description: Community and hangs in the heart of South End. Thoughtful coffee, beer, natural wines, and food.
Comments:
They have orange flavored cinnamon rolls sometimes, which I suspect they get from the same place that The Hobbyist does. The aesthetic is what I'd describe as typical of South End. Trendy, industrial chic, unfinished floor, minimalist, vibes.

Parking is free, which is rare for South End, making it one of the better picks for those driving from different neighborhoods looking for a hangout spot. It's pretty popular though, so arrive early, as I have gone here before and been unable to get a seat indoors. There's some outdoor seating though, so on a warm day, you're usually able to find a spot to sit. It's walking distance (literally seconds) from Vicente as well, so you can park once and hit two spots.

Description: A fun coffee shop and gathering space featuring a pool table, comfortable indoor and outdoor seating, themed event nights, puzzles and various board games.
Comments:
This place is in the bottom of an apartment building and across from a bunch of stores. As a result, it's popular just about every day of the week. If you want to be social and talk to people, it'd be a great spot to post up. They have a pool table and various events put on by the apartment complex (karaoke night, trivia night, stuff like that) from time to time. 

There’s very limited parking directly in front of the store but plenty more in the light rail parking garage. The staff will validate your ticket if you use the garage. Seating by outlets can be tough, maybe 2-3 spots have access, so come charged up.

Description: A brewery, coffee bar, American eatery & fermentation lab share their products all under one roof.
Comments:
Hot spot in South End for a younger crowd of remote workers. Coffee bar during the day, brewery in the evenings. Parking is free, it's a gravel lot you kind of have to keep an eye out for. Doesn't stick out from the street.

If you come here in the morning, you can have nearly the whole place to yourself. It doesn't get busy until the afternoon (South End lunch crowd). They have a handful of booths that each have outlet access, as well as some outdoor tables with outlets nearby. 

This and the Common Market in South End are my favorite remote work spots in the area, specifically because they're not that crowded in the mornings. You can also order via QR code here and have it brought to your table, so if you're an introvert, you can walk in, talk to literally no one, sit down, plug in, order, and just vibe man, just vibe. Surrounded by people, yet still alone.

Description: Seattle-based coffeehouse chain known for its signature roasts, light bites and WiFi availability.
Comments: Right next to Costco. Get some work done then go shopping. Get a hot dog and a rotisserie chicken (may they forever remain $5).

Seattle-based coffeehouse chain known for its signature roasts, light bites and WiFi availability.
Comments: This Starbucks is unique in that it sites within a converted home. Very popular spot, lot's of seating, lot's of remote workers and students hanging out.

Description: Non-profit restaurant serving breakfasts, sandwiches & salads amid warehouse-style decor.
Comments: Check out their website for details about their mission as a business. Worth visiting just to support the cause!

Address: 1440 S Tryon St UNIT 110, Charlotte, NC 28203
Description: Modern redbrick brewery with a rotating selection of draft and to-go beers, plus a beer garden.

Place: Charlotte Mecklenburg Library | South County Regional
Description: The Charlotte Mecklenburg Library is one of America’s leading urban public libraries, serving a community of more than one million citizens in Mecklenburg County, North Carolina. Through 20 locations, targeted outreach and online, the Library delivers exceptional services and programs, with a mission to improve lives and build a stronger community. In short, we strive to be essential to our community.
Comments: One of the best libraries in the area. Large quiet room, large general seating areas both upstairs and downstairs, plenty of nooks and crannies to cozy up in. A+ interior design. Vending machines downstairs if you need a snack or drink. Quality.

Description: Your newest neighborhood café, serving specialty coffee, beer, and wine with passion
Airy, laid-back brewpub pouring house beers paired with wood-fired pizzas & other modern bar bites.
Comments:
Cool. That’s the word I’d use to describe this place. It feels a little hidden being upstairs, which somehow makes it even better. The music, the eclectic decor, the paintings, the random plants, the murals, everything about it just works. It’s cool. Or hip. That word fits too.

You could honestly film one of those “cool young people spreading peace, love, and unity while hanging out with a diverse group of friends” commercials here. And I mean that in the best way possible. I don’t really know how else to describe it. It’s just cool. The only thing that's not cool is parking. It's NoDa, you'll be lucky to find a free street spot, else its paid lots.

The pizza is good, and daytime on weekdays it isn't that busy, so it's a solid place to work remotely. There's a handful of spots with outlet access, and plenty of seating. I don't drink beer, but when I do, I prefer Dos Equis I've been told what they serve here is really good. They also serve loose leaf tea if you get it "for here", which is much appreciated by tea lovers such as me.

Description: Bookseller chain stocking housebrand eReader, plus a broad selection of titles for adults & kids.
Comments:
They have a good set of the comfy couches both downstairs and upstairs, but mostly upstairs. There’s maybe 1-2 couches in a corner downstairs, but upstairs they line the window that runs the length of the building. Excellent spots to read. Premium coziness.

Downstairs there’s a Starbucks with a bunch of seating. Only 3-4 spots that are near outlets though, so charge your laptop if you’re coming to work or study. Idk why but the Starbucks inside this Barnes & Nobles has different and way better food, drink, and snack options than normal Starbucks. 

This location has marvelous cookies. The salted caramel one is 10/10. And the hot tea options are way more expansive than normal Starbucks. Harney & Sons tea options, quality stuff. So as weird as this may sound, the Starbucks inside this Barnes & Nobles is a hidden gem in and of itself.

Perhaps the only downside here is it gets super busy. This place is flooded with students meeting their tutors and study groups weekdays after school. Although you can still usually find a spot somewhere. But after church on Sunday? Forget it. This place is packed. So, just time your visit well. I’ve found, if you have remote  work flexibility, it’s plenty tranquil 9 AM - 5 PM on weekdays. It’ll just be you, the staff, a few house moms, and other remote workers. 

The parking lot is small, but you can park across the street in the gravel lot by the apartments. That’s retail parking as well. Oh and there’s a really good ice cream place in this complex. Golden Cow Creamery. Check it out.

Place: Night Swim Coffee | Bank of America Tower
Address: 620 S Tryon St Suite 150, Charlotte, NC 28202
Description: Night Swim Coffee was born in Charlotte, North Carolina as the centerpiece of a unified venture for Not Just Coffee and Undercurrent Coffee to create a specialty coffee roaster in Charlotte. In our cafes, Night Swim Coffee offers the same thoughtfully prepared food and beverages, attention to detail, and hospitable atmosphere that is enjoyed in the legacy Not Just Coffee and Undercurrent Coffee cafes, but in a setting designed in a collaborative effort across the team to create a unique experience at every location.

Address: 1620 Oakhurst Commons Dr Suite 306, Charlotte, NC 28205
Description: Specialty coffee shop from a local Charlotte roaster serving carefully crafted espresso drinks, drip coffee, and rotating single origin offerings, along with a small selection of pastries. Known for consistent quality, attention to detail, and baristas who can help you choose something new, it is a reliable stop whether you are grabbing a quick coffee or exploring more adventurous seasonal drinks.
Comments: The cinnamon sugar bagel is very good, they give you a generous amount of cream cheese. Like, almost too much, which I consider to be a good thing. Also they have a solid tea menu, not an overwhelming amount of choices, but the ones they have are a step above your standard Earl Grey, English Breakfast, and Jasmine Green teas. I'm a tea person, so any spot with good tea automatically becomes a favorite of mine. If you get the tea "for here" they give you a nice mug and a little glass holder thing with extra tea and a plate and sometimes even a gold colored (not actual gold) spoon. Very quaint. Very posh. Very "demure". I know I'm not using that word right. I don't care.

Description: Here at Waterbean Coffee, we always try to stay original and never follow the trends. In a time when most coffee shops focus on getting the customers in and out of their doors the quickest, we try to give them a place to relax, hold meetings, go over schoolwork, or just hang out with friends. We want to be more than just another coffee shop. Our founder’s international background brings a unique aspect to the space that most people don’t have. This is reflected from our menu options all the way down to our store designs. One of Tony’s favorite quotes is from Henry Ford: “Quality means doing it right when no one is looking.”
Coffee shop providing area-sourced java & pastries in a chill space with local artwork & free Wi-Fi.
Comments: About as close to a Charlotte third place institution as you can get in this city where everything, for better or worse, feels so new. You've got writers clubs that meet here, book clubs that meet here, D&D clubs that meet here, business people that take meetings here, students that study here, remote workers that work from here, it's well traveled, and for good reason. Great spot. Maybe hard to find seating during peak times, but round the corner to nearby Panera Bread, Rhino Market SouthPark, Summit Coffee SouthPark, or Tous les Jours if you can't find a spot here.

Description: Eco-minded chain with natural & organic grocery items, housewares & other products (most sell wine).
Comments: There’s downstairs seating across the whole checkout area but also an upstairs with more seating and an outdoor patio. Great spot, the only challenge is there are no publicly accessible outlets upstairs. You’ve got to come charged up.

Description: Coffeehouse chain serving signature drinks, mochas & lattes, plus coffee & breakfast.
Comments: This spot shares a space with a Bruegger's Bagels and as a result is rather large. Great access to outlets, plenty of seating, drinks from Caribou and food from Bruegger's. Great remote work spot. It also gets surprisingly calm after the lunch rush since Bruegger's closes before Caribou. It can be quite chill in the afternoons. There's also two large tables back behind the checkout counters where the restrooms are for extra seating.

Through 20 locations, targeted outreach and online, the Library delivers exceptional services and programs, with a mission to improve lives and build a stronger community. In short, we strive to be essential to our community.
Comments: My favorite library of the many marvelous ones in Charlotte. In addition to plenty of interior seating, they have a patio upstairs that overlooks this mini park area with a fountain. Great spot to read, or just sit outside and be on your laptop since the Wi-Fi extends out there.

Description: Counter-serve bakery/cafe chain serving sandwiches, salads & more, known for its bread & free WiFi.

Also, they have cinnamon rolls, and they’re quite alright. Nothing remarkable, but certainly passable. This location gets a lot of traffic during lunchtime from the nearby office park but is mostly chill after that. It’s across the street from Summit Coffee SouthPark and Tous Les Jours SouthPark and Rhino Market SouthPark so if you drive to this area, you have options.

Description: Seattle-based coffeehouse chain known for its signature roasts, light bites and WiFi availability.
Comments: This is inside a very large Harris Teeter, but it's on the list because there's a good amount of seating, including a covered patio/outdoors spot. Go get some food from the hot bar, then head in here, get your drink, and hangout.

Description: Seattle-based coffeehouse chain known for its signature roasts, light bites and WiFi availability.
Comments: This spot has an upstairs section that gives a cool sense of seclusion. It's the only Starbucks I know of in Charlotte with an upstairs. Whole Foods is right around the corner, so if you drive to this area, you've got options.

Place: Amélie’s French Bakery & Café | Rock Hill
Address: 157 E Main St, Rock Hill, SC 29730
Description: This charming gathering place draws a crowd for its pastries, light fare & coffee drinks.
Comments: This whole area of town has several third places all within walking distance. You could drive, park, and spend a day walking between this Amelie's, The Mercantile, Rock Hill Coffee, and Knowledge Perk. It's worth the drive if you're in Charlotte and haven't gone down to Rock Hill yet. Finish your day at Fountain Park for nice views and a calm relaxing atmosphere. Bring a book!

Description: This charming gathering place draws a crowd for its pastries, light fare & coffee drinks.
Comments: This isn't the original Amelie's if you've been in Charlotte long enough to remember that. They moved, so this is the new "original" in a way. The interior design is better than the original, it's bigger, the seating is arranged such that there's plenty of spots for 1-2 people to sit that are out of the way of the bigger tables. The food might be overpriced but I don't go for the food. I'm there for vibes. The vibes are great.

Place: Amélie’s French Bakery & Café | Carmel Commons
Description: This charming gathering place draws a crowd for its pastries, light fare & coffee drinks.
Comments: Seating by outlets at this location can be a little tricky here so come with a full charge. Other than that, as is consistent across all Amelie's, it's a great place to hangout and read, work, study, chill, etc.

Place: Amélie’s French Bakery & Café | Park Road
Description: This charming gathering place draws a crowd for its pastries, light fare & coffee drinks.
Comments:
One of my favorite third places in Charlotte. In fact, it was my first third place here. This location is spacious, bright, and thoughtfully designed. The ground floor has large tables that make it easy for groups to meet, and you’ll often see book clubs, church groups, and D&D squads gathered around. Even with all that activity, there always seems to be a seat for solo visitors.

The slightly raised seating area that runs the length of the building is perfect if you come alone. It’s lined with two-top tables and counters and feels a bit tucked away from the main floor. You can walk in, see families and groups filling the space, and still know there’s a quiet corner waiting for you.

Outlet access is excellent. Along the booth-style seats in the raised seating section, there’s a slim black strip beneath the padded backs with outlets. They are easy to miss, but they’re there. Someone clearly put effort into making sure people could stay a while.

Now for story time. I moved to Charlotte during the COVID-19 pandemic, which meant nearly everything worth exploring was closed. When things started reopening, smaller spots struggled with distancing, but larger ones like this Amelie’s found a way. They removed a few tables and still let people sit safely apart. After more than a year of being confined to my studio apartment, this became my first “just sit somewhere and be out of the house” spot. I would bring my laptop and a book, work remotely, watch shows, read, and just exist somewhere that wasn’t home.

I came here three or four times a week. The staff eventually started predicting my order, which is partly why I began branching out to other places. I felt I needed to be more adventurous. But this Amelie’s will always be special to me. It was my home away from home. I made my first friends in Charlotte here and saw so many others doing the same. People working, reading, studying, and talking. This spot embodies what a third place is supposed to be.

The food and pastries are alright. Nothing life-changing, but nothing bad either. The cinnamon roll is just okay, it’s gotten better. It used to be terrible, but since it’s not a French pastry, I give them a pass. The coffee is reliable, and the tea options are good. Pro tip, you can order a full pot of tea even though it’s not listed on the display menu. Between that, the pastries, and the welcoming atmosphere, everything here invites you to stay a while.

It may not be the original Amelie’s, but it’s my original. I pray it never goes away.
